2 Depression South          27.8        4.99           32.7  26.6 Female  2018
3 None       North          18.5        6.94           56.2  20.9 Male    2018
4 None       North          12.9        7.44           88.4  23.6 Female  2019
5 Depression East           24.6        4.16           54.8  28.1 Female  2020
6 Depression South          17.5        5.10           25.9  27.0 Male    2020

title: Independent Study to Consolidate
text:
Exercise 1: Histogram Practice
 Make a histogram of stress_score. Try two different bin settings and briefly note what changes.
Reflect: How does the bin size influence the level of fine detail you can see in the data?

title: Independent Study to Consolidate
text:
Exercise 2: Density Overlay Practice
 Overlay a density curve and histogram of stress_score. Alter colors / alpha levels so that it is easy to see both the density curve and histogram.

title: Independent Study to Consolidate
text:
Exercise 3: Categorical Distributions Practice
 Compare stress_score across diagnosis groups using either a boxplot or a violin (your choice). Add jittered points (transparent) and mark the mean with stat_summary().
Reflect: Do the means and medians overlap? Are there group differences between diagnoses?

title: Practical
text:
In this practical you will read in a dataset and plot distributions in various ways. You will also get a bit of practice with tidyverse data wrangling.

Practicals are not a test. It is expected that you often don’t know how to start, make a lot of mistakes and need help. It is expected that you are familiar with independent study content before the workshop. However, you need not remember or understand every detail as the workshop should build and consolidate your understanding. Tips

don’t worry about making mistakes
don’t let what you can not do interfere with what you can do
discussing code with your neighbours will help
look things up in the independent study material
look things up in your own code from earlier workshops
there are no stupid questions







Key



These four symbols are used at the beginning of each instruction so you know where to carry out the instruction.
 Something you need to do on your computer. It may be opening programs or documents or locating a file.
 Something you should do in RStudio. It will often be typing a command or using the menus but might also be creating folders, locating or moving files.
 Something you should do in your browser on the internet. It may be searching for information, going to the VLE or downloading a file.
 A question for you to think about and answer. Record your answers in your script for future reference.

title: Practical
text: In this practical you will read in a dataset and plot distributions in various ways. You will also get a bit of practice with tidyverse data wrangling.

title: Practical
text:
Practicals are not a test. It is expected that you often don’t know how to start, make a lot of mistakes and need help. It is expected that you are familiar with independent study content before the workshop. However, you need not remember or understand every detail as the workshop should build and consolidate your understanding. Tips

don’t worry about making mistakes
don’t let what you can not do interfere with what you can do
discussing code with your neighbours will help
look things up in the independent study material
look things up in your own code from earlier workshops
there are no stupid questions







Key



These four symbols are used at the beginning of each instruction so you know where to carry out the instruction.
 Something you need to do on your computer. It may be opening programs or documents or locating a file.
 Something you should do in RStudio. It will often be typing a command or using the menus but might also be creating folders, locating or moving files.
 Something you should do in your browser on the internet. It may be searching for information, going to the VLE or downloading a file.
 A question for you to think about and answer. Record your answers in your script for future reference.

title: Practical
text:
Wellbeing
We’ll be working with a simulated dataset is based on a fictional cross-sectional survey study exploring the relationships between social support, therapy attendance, loneliness, sleep quality, and overall wellbeing in adults.
In this fictional study, participants were recruited from community mental health clinics and general community advertisements between 2019 and 2022. They completed a survey assessing:

Perceived social support (categorized as Low, Medium, or High)
Current therapy status (Yes or No)
Loneliness (a standardized loneliness score; higher scores indicate greater loneliness)
Subjective wellbeing (higher scores indicate better wellbeing)
Sleep quality (rated on a 1–10 scale)
Demographics, including age and sex

The fictional study aimed to understand how social support and therapy might relate to feelings of loneliness and overall wellbeing, as well as how these factors interact with sleep and demographic characteristics.

title: Practical
text:
Packages
Remember that packages, such as ggplot2 (Wickham 2016) need to be installed once and then loaded each session. ggplot2 is one of the tidyverse (Wickham et al. 2019) packages.
Today, we’ll be using tidyverse and ggridges






Important



If you are working on a University computer (or the VDS) you do not need to install tidyverse.
If you are working on your own computer or using RStudio cloud you do need to install tidyverse.


To install a package:
 Go the Packages tab on the lower right pane. Click Install and type the name of the package into the box that appears.
Wait until you get the prompt back. It will take a few moments, be patient!
To use a package which is installed you have to load it with the library() function. You will need to do this whether you are working on your own computer or on a University computer
 Load the tidyverse and ggridges. Type or copy the following code into your R script:

library(tidyverse)
library(ggridges)

title: Practical
text:
Reading in data
You will go into more depth about reading in data in the Data Analysis module For now, you can just follow these steps.
 Save this file in your week-3 folder:

Data from fictional wellbeing study: therapy_data.csv


 Add the following code to your R script and run:

therapy_df <- read_csv("therapy_data.csv")

title: Practical
text:
Look at data
 Examine the variables and first few rows of the therapy_df object using head()

head(therapy_df)

# A tibble: 6 × 8
  support_level therapy   age loneliness_score wellbeing_score sleep_quality
  <chr>         <chr>   <dbl>            <dbl>           <dbl>         <dbl>
1 Medium        No         42             30.4            58.6             6
2 Low           Yes        23             72.2            44.5             6
3 Low           No         35             47.1            39.8             7
4 Medium        No         23             35.1            56.8             8
5 Medium        Yes        20             57.0            60.6             6
6 Medium        No         40             47.2            61.5             6
# ℹ 2 more variables: sex <chr>, year <dbl>


See that you have a table where each column is a variable from the fictional study, such as wellbeing_score. Each row contains values for each variable for one participant.

title: Practical
text:
Exercise 1: Histograms
Look at the distribution of the loneliness_score variable.
 Plot the distribution by creating a plot in which the x-axis variable is loneliness_score and the distribution of this variable is shown as a histogram.








 Try different numbers of bins (e.g., 10, 30, 50)
 Look up the named colors
 Choose a color from the list and use it to change the fill color of your histogram

title: Practical
text:
Exercise 2: Comparing distributions in groups
A density plot allows us to look at the overall shape of the distribution, rather than counts of values within bins.
 Create a density plot of loneliness_score.

ggplot(therapy_df, aes(x = loneliness_score)) +
  geom_density()







We can examine both the histogram and density plot by overlaying them.
 Overlay density and histogram of loneliness_score.

ggplot(therapy_df, aes(x = loneliness_score, y = after_stat(density))) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 5, fill = "blue", 
                 color = "black", alpha = 0.5) +
  geom_density()







What if we want to examine how loneliness_score varies across groups, such as people with different levels of support (in the support_level variable)? One way we can look at this is to overlay the density of loneliness_score for each support_level.
To do this, we can copy the density plot from the first part of this exercise, but within the brackets for geom_density(), use support_level to control the fill aesthetic.
 Copy your code for plotting loneliness_score density, and add some aes() code within the geom_density() to fill based on support_level.








See that the fill is opaque, so the densities cover each other up. We can make them transparent by setting alpha to a value lower than 1, as we did in the histogram above.
 Set the alpha level for geom_density() to 0.5.

title: Practical
text:
Exercise 3: Boxplots
Our last density plot allowed us to get a sense of how the distributions of loneliness_score varied for different levels of support (support_level). But, we might find that visual a bit crowded. Perhaps we want to get a more compact depiction of the distributions and visually separate distributions for each support_level. One way to do this is to use boxplots.
 Create this basic boxplot

ggplot(therapy_df, aes(x = support_level, y = loneliness_score)) +
  geom_boxplot()







What if we want to keep the compact format of the boxplot, but also see the distribution of individual points?
 Add a geom_jitter() line to show individual observations








 This is a little busy! Set alpha for geom_jitter() to below 1, e.g., 0.2.








Boxplots show medians and quartiles. We can plot additional summary statistics, like mean values, using stat_summary()
 Copy the code below to add a point indicating the mean value, and edit the content within stat_summary() to change the color of the points.

ggplot(therapy_df, aes(x = support_level, y = loneliness_score)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  stat_summary(fun = mean, geom = "point")

title: Practical
text:
Exercise 4: Violin plots
The boxplots we just generated were less crowded than the overlapping density plots. However, this advantage came at a cost: we can no longer see the shape of the distribution. A violin plot allows us to compare the shape of the distribution for one variable across levels of another variable.
 Generate this basic violin plot

ggplot(therapy_df, aes(x = support_level, y = loneliness_score)) +
  geom_violin()







If we want to combine the advantages of a boxplot (compact depiction of medians and quartiles) with the advantages of a violinplot (showing the shapes of the distributions), we can overlay them.
 Overlay a violin and boxplot

ggplot(therapy_df, aes(x = support_level, y = loneliness_score)) + 
  geom_violin() +
  geom_boxplot()







Hm, these boxplots are very big and cover up parts of the violin plots underneath!
 Within geom_boxplot(), change the width to something narrower, like 0.1








 To help us visually compare the distributions, within geom_violin(), use support_level to control the fill aesthetic

title: Practical
text:
Exercise 5: Ridgeline plots
You might have noticed that each “violin” in a violin plot essentially shows the distribution twice (the two “sides” of the violin). Ridgeline plots allow you to show each distribution once in a nice visually separated way.
 Generate a basic ridgeline plot

ggplot(therapy_df, aes(x = loneliness_score, y = support_level)) +
  geom_density_ridges()







 Use support_level to control the fill aesthetic of geom_density_ridges() and set the overall alpha level to less than 1 (e.g., 0.5)

title: Practical
text:
Exercise 6: Wrangling practice with visualization
Currently, our dataset contains a lot of information. But we may want to go beyond the exact data in the dataset.
For example, we might want to look at differences in wellbeing for people who are low versus high in loneliness. We can’t do this with the data as-is because loneliness_score is a continuous variable.
This poses an extremely common data wrangling issue: we need to use the data we have to derive some new values of interest.
 Use mutate and ifelse to create a new variable called loneliness_level in which loneliness_scrores above the median value are high and those at or below median are low.

# This code generates the new variable
therapy_df <- therapy_df %>%
  mutate(loneliness_level = ifelse(loneliness_score > median(loneliness_score), "high", "low"))

# We can see that this new variable is added to therapy_df
head(therapy_df)

# A tibble: 6 × 9
  support_level therapy   age loneliness_score wellbeing_score sleep_quality
  <chr>         <chr>   <dbl>            <dbl>           <dbl>         <dbl>
1 Medium        No         42             30.4            58.6             6
2 Low           Yes        23             72.2            44.5             6
3 Low           No         35             47.1            39.8             7
4 Medium        No         23             35.1            56.8             8
5 Medium        Yes        20             57.0            60.6             6
6 Medium        No         40             47.2            61.5             6
# ℹ 3 more variables: sex <chr>, year <dbl>, loneliness_level <chr>


 Use either a boxplot, violin plot, or ridge plot to depict the distribution of wellbeing_score for each loneliness_level: your choice!
You’re finished!

title: Independent Study to Prepare
text:
Preparation for Weeks 2 and 3: Get Acquainted with Tidy Data Wrangling
This preparation involves reading some chapters in an online book and getting started with an online DataCamp course. I will recommend this preparation for weeks 2 and 3. You can try taking an initial look in week 2, and revisit the reading more deeply in week 3.
Although the focus of this module is on data visualisation, before you visualise data, you often need to take some steps to get it into a form that you can visualise. These steps are often referred to using phrases like “data management” and “data wrangling”. These days, it is common practice in R to perform steps to ensure that your data are in a standard, “tidy” format in which data are stored in a table where each row is an observation and each column is a variable. Common steps for preparing data for visualisation and analysis include:

Generating summary statistics, such as the mean value of an outcome variable for groups of participants
Selecting a subset of data, such as a subset of variables, or rows for just participants in a subset of groups

The Data Analysis module that you will be completing at the same time will cover many common tidy data wrangling steps, particularly in Weeks 3 and 4. Therefore, we won’t spend much time covering these steps in the seminars for Data Visualisation. However, since this is a crucial part of working with data in R, you will benefit from getting acquainted with it for this module as well.
There are many resources for learning about tidy data wrangling. You are encouraged to try the following two resources:

Read Tidyverse Ch 4 - 7
DataCamp courses on tidyverse and tidy wrangling:

Introduction to the Tidyverse
Categorical Data in the Tidyverse
Reshaping Data with tidyr

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
Today

The grammar of graphics

How graphics are constructed in R (standard)

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
Packages

To expand R’s capabilities, we often need to use packages
The main package we’ll be using to generate graphics is ggplot2

install.packages("ggplot2")
library(ggplot2)

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot


What is the grammar of graphics?
A framework for building plots by combining basic building blocks, e.g.,:

geometric objects (like points or bars)
data
visual mappings (like position and color)

in a consistent, structured way

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot


A graphic…


maps variables in the data +
to the aesthetic attributes +
of geometric objects +



with possible …



statistical transformations +
different coordinate systems +
and faceting

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
section: How do we “map” data to a graphic?
text:
How do we “map” data to a graphic?


The way we depict variables in our data as axes, bars, points, etc. dictates the way that patterns such as comparisons and changes are perceived
A non-exhaustive list:

length
color (or saturation)
position
size
shape
area
angle

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
section: How are variables depicted here? What does it communicate?

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot


Bulding blocks


data
aesthetics: specify variables to use for axes, shapes
geom: the shapes that will depict the data
scales: customise how variables are used to depict axes, shapes
statistical transformations: depict summaries (e.g., means) and model fits
coord: customise axis ranges and appearance
theme: customise features such as font size, background color, legend position
facets: break graphic into subsets




TODAY I”M GIVING YOU AN OVERVIEW OF WHAT THESE BUILDING BLOCKS ARE AND HOW TO PUT THEM TOGETHER.
YOU MAY NOT CATCH ALL THE DETAILS NOW. THIS IS WHY WE’LL BE DIVING IN TO HOW TO USE THESE BUILDING BLOCKS FOR THE NEXT 4 WEEKS.

text:
ggplot


Bulding blocks

data
aesthetics: specify variables to use for axes, shapes
geom: the shapes that will depict the data
scales: customise how variables are used to depict axes, shapes
statistical transformations: depict summaries (e.g., means) and model fits
coord: customise axis ranges and appearance
theme: customise features such as font size, background color, legend position
facets: break graphic into subsets

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text: ggplot

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text: ggplot

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text: ggplot

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot


Bulding blocks

data
aesthetics: specify variables to use for axes, shapes
geom: the shapes that will depict the data
scales: customise how variables are used to depict axes, shapes
statistical transformations: depict summaries (e.g., means) and model fits
coord: customise axis ranges and appearance
theme: customise features such as font size, background color, legend position
facets: break graphic into subsets

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot

ggplot(data = psych_df, aes(x = stress_score))



We can choose a variable to plot

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot

ggplot(data = psych_df, aes(x = stress_score)) +
  geom_histogram()


But we need to tell ggplot what GEOMETRY to use to visualize that variable. Here, a histogram

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot

ggplot(data = psych_df, aes(x = diagnosis, y = stress_score)) +
  geom_boxplot()


Now, what if we wanted to keep looking at that distribution of stress, but break it down by diagnosis? Here, we need to add that diagnosis variable as an axis and choose a geometry to depict it. We’ll try boxplot.

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot

ggplot(data = psych_df, aes(x = diagnosis, y = stress_score)) +
  geom_violin()



Or violin plot

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot

psych_df %>%
  group_by(diagnosis) %>%
  summarize(stress_score_mean = mean(stress_score)) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = diagnosis, y = stress_score_mean)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity")


What if we don’t want to look at the full distribution - we just want to look at the average tendencies for each diagnosis? Well here we want a bar plot. But we need to calculate that average tendency somehow.
One way to do that would be to use the data to calculate the averages first, and then plot them.

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot

psych_df %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = sleep_hours, y = stress_score)) +
  geom_point()


Suppose we want to see, beyond diagnosis, are there variables associated with stress? How about sleep? Now we’re looking at a relationship between continuous variables, so the appropriate choice here is a scatterplot. So the geeometry we’ll use is points in a scatterplot.

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot

psych_df %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = sleep_hours, y = stress_score)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = diagnosis))


What if we want to incorporate another variable into this plot. E.g., what if we want to visualize stress, sleep AND diagnosis? We can control another aesthetic using the diagnosis variable - e.g., point color

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot

psych_df %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = sleep_hours, y = stress_score)) +
  geom_point(aes(shape = diagnosis))


We could use diagnosis to control another aesthetic, like shape

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot

psych_df %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = stress_score, y = diagnosis)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = sleep_hours))


We could change the way we map our variables to aesthetics - axes, shapes

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot


Bulding blocks

data
aesthetics: specify variables to use for axes, shapes
geom: the shapes that will depict the data
scales: customise how variables are used to depict axes, shapes
statistical transformations: depict summaries (e.g., means) and model fits
coord: customise axis ranges and appearance
theme: customise features such as font size, background color, legend position
facets: break graphic into subsets

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot

psych_df %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = sleep_hours, y = stress_score)) +
  geom_point()


Customize how the variables are plotted as points

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot

psych_df %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = sleep_hours, y = stress_score)) +
  geom_point(color = "blue", size = 2)


Customize how the variables are plotted as points

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot

psych_df %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = sleep_hours, y = stress_score)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = diagnosis), size = 2)


Use another variable to control the color

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot

psych_df %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = sleep_hours, y = stress_score)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = diagnosis), size = 2) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("darkgray", "deeppink", "blue")) +
  scale_x_continuous(name = "Sleep in Hours", 
                     breaks = seq(0, 12, by = 2), limits = c(0, 12))


Use another variable to control the color and customise

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot


Bulding blocks

data
aesthetics: specify variables to use for axes, shapes
geom: the shapes that will depict the data
scales: customise how variables are used to depict axes, shapes
statistical transformations: depict summaries (e.g., means) and model fits
coord: customise axis ranges and appearance
theme: customise features such as font size, background color, legend position
facets: break graphic into subsets

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot

psych_df %>%
  group_by(diagnosis) %>%
  summarize(stress_score_mean = mean(stress_score)) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = diagnosis, y = stress_score_mean)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity")


What if we want to change how the axes are depicted?

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot

psych_df %>%
  group_by(diagnosis) %>%
  summarize(stress_score_mean = mean(stress_score)) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = diagnosis, y = stress_score_mean)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity") +
  coord_cartesian(ylim = c(10, 40))

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot

psych_df %>%
  group_by(diagnosis) %>%
  summarize(stress_score_mean = mean(stress_score)) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = diagnosis, y = stress_score_mean)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity") +
  coord_flip()


Change the orientation

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot


Bulding blocks

data
aesthetics: specify variables to use for axes, shapes
geom: the shapes that will depict the data
scales: customise how variables are used to depict axes, shapes
statistical transformations: depict summaries (e.g., means) and model fits
coord: customise axis ranges and appearance
theme: customise features such as font size, background color, legend position
facets: break graphic into subsets

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot

psych_df %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = sleep_hours, y = stress_score)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = diagnosis), size = 2) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("darkgray", "deeppink", "blue")) +
  scale_x_continuous(name = "Sleep in Hours", 
                     breaks = seq(0, 12, by = 2), limits = c(0, 12)) 


We often want to control the other aspects of appearance, such as font size

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot

psych_df %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = sleep_hours, y = stress_score)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = diagnosis), size = 2) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("darkgray", "deeppink", "blue")) +
  scale_x_continuous(name = "Sleep in Hours", 
                     breaks = seq(0, 12, by = 2), limits = c(0, 12)) +
  theme(legend.position = "top",
        legend.title = element_blank(),
        panel.grid = element_blank())


We can add a theme() code and specify the appearance of various characteristics

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot

psych_df %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = sleep_hours, y = stress_score)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = diagnosis), size = 2) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("darkgray", "deeppink", "blue")) +
  scale_x_continuous(name = "Sleep in Hours", 
                     breaks = seq(0, 12, by = 2), limits = c(0, 12)) +
  theme_bw()


There are also built-in themes that control many characteristics at once

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot


Bulding blocks

data
aesthetics: specify variables to use for axes, shapes
geom: the shapes that will depict the data
scales: customise how variables are used to depict axes, shapes
statistical transformations: depict summaries (e.g., means) and model fits
coord: customise axis ranges and appearance
theme: customise features such as font size, background color, legend position
facets: break graphic into subsets



Facets are especially handy when we have some pattern of relationships between some variables, and we want to see how that pattern VARIES ACROSS DIFFERENT GROUPS.

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot

psych_df %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = sex, y = stress_score)) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = .1))


What if we want to see how this relationship varies across another variable? Like different diagnoses? Too much to combine into a single plot

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
ggplot

psych_df %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = sex, y = stress_score)) +
  facet_wrap(~diagnosis) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = .1))


Instead, break across facets

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
Summary: Grammar of Graphics

Minimum for plot = data + aes() + geom()
Map variables to aesthetics: x, y, color/fill, shape, size, alpha, linetype.
Pick geoms to match the question: hist/box/violin (distributions), bar (summaries/counts), point (relationships).
Use stats when needed: stat_summary() for means/SE; stat=“identity” when you’ve already computed values.
Tune scales & labels: scale_*_*(), labs().
Adjust axes/orientation: coord_cartesian(), coord_flip(), coord_polar().
Polish appearance: theme(), built-ins (theme_bw())
Compare subsets with facets: facet_wrap() / facet_grid().

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
Workflow checklist

Start with a clear question.
Choose mappings (what goes to x/y/color/…?).
Select geom (how should it look?).
Add stat/facet if it clarifies the story.
Refine with scales/coord; label units.
Finish with theme
Check clarity & integrity

title: Week 2 Seminar: Grammar of Graphics
text:
Upcoming
What is the range and shape of our data?
Dive into distributions

title: Overview
text:
This week you will get an introduction to the standard approach to creating visualisations in R. There is a preparation step to get acquainted with standard data management in R.

Learning objectives
The successful student will be able to:

generate common types of graphs, including histograms, barplots, and scatterplots
customise the way variables are used to generate the axes and contents of the graph
customise the appearance of graphs, including colors and axis ranges

title: Independent Study to Consolidate
text:
As in Week 9, these consolidation exercises will ask you to apply what you learned in the seminar and practical to another dataset.
In these exercises, you will re-use a dataset and code from an earlier week to create your own Shiny dashboard-style app, using the same core ideas as before plus the new layout and server tools from Week 10:

A single app.R file with a ui and server
A sidebar layout with inputs on the left and outputs on the right
Inputs that filter the data and switch between multiple outcomes
Multiple tabs (tabsetPanel(), tabPanel()) that show different plots
A tab-specific control (for example, a checkbox that turns faceting on/off)
A reusable reactive filtered dataset created with reactive()
Efficient mapping from the outcome dropdown to ggplot using .data[[input$outcome]]

The goal is to consolidate the new Shiny features from Week 10 using a dataset you already know.






Key



These four symbols are used at the beginning of each instruction so you know where to carry out the instruction.
 Something you need to do on your computer outside of RStudio. It may be opening programs or documents or locating a file.
 Something you should do in RStudio. It will usually involve writing or running R code, but might also be creating folders, locating or moving files.
 Something you should do in your browser, like searching for information, going to the VLE or downloading a file.
 A question for you to think about and answer. You should usually record your answers in your script/app for future reference.





Start by deciding what you want your Week 10 app to explore.
For a rich enough dataset to produce multiple plots and variations, you may want to adapt the Week 5 or Week 6 dataset (the Week 4 dataset may not have enough variables / patterns to make use of the Week 10 features).
 Open the R script from your chosen week and quickly skim what you did.
 Note:

Which dataset you plan to use
Which two continuous outcomes you might let the user switch between (for the outcome dropdown)
Which grouping variable you might:

use as a filter (in a checkbox group)
use in a facet or second tab





Create a fresh project for this Week 10 consolidation app.
 In RStudio, in the Files tab (bottom-right panel), create a new folder somewhere sensible (for example inside data-visualisation-in-r). Give it a clear name that relates to the graphs you will use in the app, such as consolidate10_dashboard.
We will refer to this as project_name/.
Your goal is to have a structure like:
project_name/
  project_name.Rproj
  app.R
  data/
    <one or more CSV files>
 Turn this folder into an RStudio Project:

Click the project dropdown in the top-right of RStudio

Choose New Project → Existing Directory

Select your new project_name/ folder and click Create Project

 Inside this project, create a subfolder called data.
 Copy the relevant CSV file(s) from the original week into this data folder.



 In RStudio (inside your new project):

Create a new R Script and save it as app.R in project_name/.

At the top of app.R, load the packages you need, for example:
library(shiny)
library(tidyverse)
library(viridis)
Then load your dataset from the data/ folder, using a clear object name:
my_df <- readr::read_csv("data/your_dataset.csv")
Replace "your_dataset.csv" and my_df with names that make sense for your data.
If you have a grouping variable, you may want to reorder it with factor() and levels = ... as in earlier weeks.
 In a brief comment above your data-loading code, describe: - What the dataset represents - Which variables you expect to use in your app



 Make sure app.R contains the basic Shiny structure:
ui <- fluidPage(

)

server <- function(input, output, session) {

}

shinyApp(ui = ui, server = server)



In Week 10 we moved from a simple fluidPage() with a single plot to a sidebar layout with multiple tabs.
Your goal is to have a UI structure like this:
ui <- fluidPage(
  titlePanel("Your dashboard title"),
  p("Short instructions for what users can explore."),

  sidebarLayout(
    sidebarPanel(
      # inputs (dropdowns, checkboxes, etc.)
    ),
    mainPanel(
      tabsetPanel(
        tabPanel(
          title = "Tab 1 title",
          # tab-specific inputs (if any) and plotOutput(...)
        ),
        tabPanel(
          title = "Tab 2 title",
          # tab-specific inputs (if any) and plotOutput(...)
        )
      )
    )
  )
)
 Edit your ui <- fluidPage(...) so that it:

Includes a titlePanel() with a clear title

Includes a short p() paragraph explaining what the app will show

Uses sidebarLayout() with sidebarPanel() and mainPanel()

Inside mainPanel(), uses tabsetPanel() with two tabPanel()s, such as:

Tab 1: a view focused on one grouping (e.g., group differences)
Tab 2: a view that uses faceting or a different outcome


Each tab should contain at least one plotOutput() with a clear name
 Save app.R and click Run App. You should see:

A title and short paragraph

A sidebar on the left (currently empty)

Two tabs with empty plot areas on the right




Now you’ll add global inputs in the sidebar that affect both tabs, such as:

A dropdown to choose between two continuous outcomes

A checkbox group filter to control which groups appear in the plots

 In a comment inside sidebarPanel(), note:

Which variable you will use for the outcome dropdown (two options)

Which variable you will use for the group filter (e.g., support level, participant group, job type)

 Inside sidebarPanel(), add:

A selectInput() for a dropdown menu. Remember to fill out the inputID, label, choices and selected arguments.
A checkboxGroupInput(). Remember to fill out the inputID, label, choices and selected arguments.

 Inside one of the tabPanels, add:

A checkboxInput(). Remember to fill out the inputID, label, and value arguments.

 Save app.R and click Run App. Check that the input controls all appear as intended.



In Week 10, we used a reactive expression to filter the data once and reuse it across multiple plots.
You will now create a filtered_data() function that:

Starts from your dataset
Filters rows where the grouping variable is in the input$group_filter vector
Updates automatically whenever the user changes the group checkboxes

 In the server function, above any plotting code, add a reactive expression that creates a function called filtered_data.
 In a comment above filtered_data <- reactive({ ... }), explain what this reactive expression does in your dataset / app.



Now you’ll create the first tab’s plot, which will:

Use filtered_data() so it respects the group filter

Plot the intended variable on the x-axis
Plot the selected outcome (from the dropdown) on the other axis using .data[[input$outcome]]
Show a clear pattern (e.g., group differences, trends over time, etc.)

 Inside the server function, add a new output using renderPlot() whose name matches the plotOutput() in your first tab, for example:
output$view1_plot <- renderPlot({

  # 1) use a small if/else block to decide on the axis label based on input$outcome

  # 2) start from filtered_data() and pipe into ggplot()

  # 3) inside aes(), use something like:
  #    x = grouping_variable,
  #    y = .data[[input$outcome]]

  # 4) add geom layer(s) to show the pattern (boxplot, line, bar, etc)

  # 5) add labs(), scales, and theme tweaks to make it readable

})



For your second tab, you will:

Use filtered_data() again

Show a different view of the data (for example, a different grouping or layout)

 In the server function, add another renderPlot() for the second tab, e.g.:
output$view2_plot <- renderPlot({

  # 1) use a small if/else block to decide on the axis label

  # 2) start from filtered_data() and pipe into ggplot()

  # 3) use aes(...) including .data[[input$outcome]] as needed

  # 4) build a base plot: e.g., outcome by another grouping, or a distribution plot

  # 5) then, use an if(){} block to test whether the checkbox is TRUE (checked), and add a plot layer if so

  # 6) in one line, just enter the name of the plot so Shiny can draw it

})
 Save app.R and click Run App. Test that:

Both tabs show plots using the current dropdown and group filter

The tab-specific checkbox only affects the second tab

Tick/untick the checkbox and make sure the change makes sense for your plot




In this final exercise, you’ll tidy your dashboard and make sure you understand how each part works.
 In app.R, add short comments to remind your future self what each major section does
 Consider making small polish edits
 In a comment in app.R, consider:

What question(s) is your dashboard helping to answer about this dataset?

How did using a reactive filtered dataset and .data[[input$outcome]] change how you structured your code compared to Week 9?

title: Independent Study to Consolidate
text:
Start by deciding what you want your Week 10 app to explore.
For a rich enough dataset to produce multiple plots and variations, you may want to adapt the Week 5 or Week 6 dataset (the Week 4 dataset may not have enough variables / patterns to make use of the Week 10 features).
 Open the R script from your chosen week and quickly skim what you did.
 Note:

Which dataset you plan to use
Which two continuous outcomes you might let the user switch between (for the outcome dropdown)
Which grouping variable you might:

use as a filter (in a checkbox group)
use in a facet or second tab

title: Practical
text:
In this practical you’ll extend your Shiny skills by building a small dashboard-style app using the wellbeing dataset, applying the ideas from Seminar 10:

Using a sidebar layout with inputs on the left and outputs on the right

Creating a checkbox group filter to control which groups appear in the plots

Using tabs in the main panel to show multiple plots in one app

Writing a reactive expression with reactive() to create a reusable filtered dataset

Using .data[[input$outcome]] inside ggplot() to avoid long if / else blocks

Adding a tab-specific control (checkbox) to switch faceting on and off

These exercises will walk you through building an app similar to the one you saw in the seminar. You can download the finished example from the seminar (which contains extensive comments / explanations) here:

app.R

By the end, you should have a working multi-tab Shiny dashboard that lets you explore wellbeing and sleep across participant groups.

Practicals are not a test. It is expected that you’ll often be unsure what to do at first – that’s normal. The goal is that each workshop helps you build confidence step-by-step.
Some tips:

don’t worry about making mistakes

don’t let what you can’t do interfere with what you can do

discussing code with your neighbours will help

look things up in the independent study material

look things up in your own code from earlier weeks

there are no stupid questions







Key



These four symbols are used at the beginning of each instruction so you know where to carry out the instruction.
 Something you need to do on your computer. It may be opening programs or documents or locating a file.
 Something you should do in RStudio. It will usually involve running R code, but might also be creating folders, locating or moving files.
 Something you should do in your browser. It will usually be searching for information, going to the VLE or downloading a file.
 A question for you to think about and answer. You can record your answers in your report, app file, or notes for future reference.

title: Practical
section: Exercise 1: Create a new Shiny project folder
text:
Exercise 1: Create a new Shiny project folder
In this exercise you will create a new folder for a mini Shiny project, add a data subfolder for the CSV, and turn it into an RStudio project.
 In the Files tab in the lower right pane, click on the ... on the right (this should say “Go to directory” when you hover over it). Clicking the ‘…’ will open the Go to folder window. Navigate to a place on your computer where you keep your work for this module (for example your data-visualisation-in-r folder). Click Open.
 In the Files tab, click on New Folder. Give your new folder a short, sensible name for this project, such as week-10-shiny-dashboard.
We’ll refer to this folder as project_name/ in the instructions below.
 Still in the Files tab, click into your new project_name/ folder. Then use File → New Project… → Existing Directory, choose your project_name/ folder, and create an R Project there.
You should now have:
project_name/
  project_name.Rproj
 Inside project_name/, create a new subfolder called data.
project_name/
  project_name.Rproj
  data/
Now you’ll add the data file.
 Download the wellbeing CSV file for this practical:

wellbeing_dataset.csv

 Save wellbeing_dataset.csv inside the data subfolder of your new project:
project_name/
  project_name.Rproj
  data/
    wellbeing_dataset.csv

title: Practical
section: Exercise 2: Create app.R and load the data
text:
Exercise 2: Create app.R and load the data
Next, you’ll create your main Shiny app script (app.R) and load the data.
 In RStudio, go to File → New File → R Script.
 Save this file in your project_name/ folder with the name app.R.
You should now have:
project_name/
  project_name.Rproj
  app.R
  data/
    wellbeing_dataset.csv
Now add the code that loads your packages and data at the top of app.R.
 In app.R, add code that:

Loads the shiny and tidyverse packages, and any others you might want (e.g., viridis for colours).

Reads in wellbeing_dataset.csv from the data folder and assigns it to an object called wellbeing_df. - Uses mutate() and factor() to order participant_group as a factor with levels "student", "employed" and "retired".

Sets a simple base theme, for example using theme_minimal(base_size = 14).

Your code will be similar in spirit to Week 9, but remember that this time you are working inside a new project folder.

title: Practical
section: Exercise 3: Add a minimal Shiny app skeleton
text:
Exercise 3: Add a minimal Shiny app skeleton
A Shiny app needs three main parts:

a UI that defines what the app looks like

a server function that defines how the app behaves

a final line that calls shinyApp(ui = ..., server = ...)


In this exercise you’ll set up a minimal skeleton app that does nothing yet, but runs without errors.
 In app.R, underneath the library and data-loading code from Exercise 2, add the following skeleton:
ui <- fluidPage(

)

server <- function(input, output, session) {

}

shinyApp(ui = ui, server = server)
 Click Run App in RStudio. You should see a mostly blank Shiny window with just a title bar and empty page.

title: Practical
section: Exercise 4: Build a sidebar layout and inputs
text:
Exercise 4: Build a sidebar layout and inputs
Now you’ll build a UI that uses a sidebar layout, with controls on the left and plots on the right.
Your UI will include:

a title

a short instructional paragraph

a sidebarLayout with:

a sidebarPanel containing inputs

a mainPanel that will later contain tabs with plots



 In app.R, edit the ui <- fluidPage(...) so that it contains:

A titlePanel() with a clear title, e.g. "Wellbeing and Sleep Dashboard".

A short instruction paragraph with p(), explaining what the app shows.

A sidebarLayout() with two parts: sidebarPanel() and mainPanel().

Next, you’ll add inputs to the sidebar panel.
 Inside sidebarPanel(...), add:

A selectInput() using the inputId "outcome" that lets the user choose between Wellbeing index and Sleep hours.

Use the choices and selected arguments to control what appears in the dropdown and which option is selected by default.

For example, your choices vector should map readable labels to column names in the data (e.g., "Wellbeing index" = "wellbeing_index").


A checkboxGroupInput() using the inputId "group_filter" that lets the user choose which participant groups to include: "student", "employed" and "retired".

Use the choices argument to list these three groups.

Use the selected argument to make all three groups selected by default.



Make sure that all of these lines live inside the parentheses of sidebarPanel(...), which itself lives inside sidebarLayout(...).
 Save app.R, then click Run App again. You should now see your title, instruction text, a dropdown menu, a group of checkboxes, and an empty main panel on the right.

title: Practical
section: Exercise 5: Add tabs to the main panel
text:
Exercise 5: Add tabs to the main panel
Now you’ll add multiple tabs in the main panel so your app can show more than one plot.
You’ll create two tabs:

A tab that compares outcomes across participant groups

A tab that shows distributions of the selected outcome, with an option to facet by group

 In app.R, edit the mainPanel(...) so that it uses tabsetPanel() with two tabPanel()s:

A first tab called "Groups" that contains a plotOutput("group_plot").

A second tab called "Distributions" that contains:

A checkboxInput() with inputId = "facet_by_group" that controls whether to show separate panels for each group (default value FALSE).

A plotOutput("distribution_plot").



 Save app.R and click Run App. You should now see:

Tabs called Groups and Distributions in the main panel

Under Distributions, a checkbox and an empty plot area

The app won’t draw any plots yet - you’ll add code to make the app draw plots in a later step.

title: Practical
section: Exercise 6: Add a reactive filtered dataset
text:
Exercise 6: Add a reactive filtered dataset
In Seminar 10, you saw how to use a reactive expression to create a function that returns a filtered dataset based on user input.
Here, you’ll create a filtered_data() function that:

Starts from wellbeing_df

Keeps only observations whose participant_group is in input$group_filter

Updates automatically whenever the user changes the group checkboxes

Remember: input$group_filter is a vector of strings (e.g., c("student", "employed", "retired")). The specific strings in this vector depend on which boxes are ticked.
 In app.R, go to the server function. Inside the curly braces {}, above any plotting code, add a reactive expression:

Use filtered_data <- reactive({ ... })

Inside the curly braces for reactive({ ... }), write tidyverse code that:

Starts from wellbeing_df

Uses filter() with %in% and input$group_filter to keep only rows whose participant_group is currently selected



 What is one advantage of using a filtered_data() reactive expression instead of repeating the same filter() code inside each plot?

title: Practical
section: Exercise 7: Build the Groups tab plot with .data[[input$outcome]]
text:
Exercise 7: Build the Groups tab plot with .data[[input$outcome]]

Next, you’ll create the plot for the Groups tab. To create this plot:

Use a simple if/else block to set the y-axis label based on input$outcome

Use filtered_data() so it only shows selected groups

Put participant_group on the x-axis

Put the selected outcome (wellbeing or sleep) on the y-axis using .data[[input$outcome]]

Use boxplots coloured by group

 Still inside the server function, add code to create an output called group_plot using renderPlot():
output$group_plot <- renderPlot({
  
  # you will write code here that:
  # uses an if/else statement to set the y-axis label based on input$outcome
  # filters data and pipes it into a ggplot
  # creates a ggplot that puts `participant_group` on the x-axis 
  # and `.data[[input$outcome]]` for on the y-axis
  # adds ggplot layer(s) to create colored boxplots
  # adds any labs, colors, fills, and theme option layers 

})
 Save app.R and click Run App. Try:

Checking and unchecking different participant groups in the sidebar

Switching between Wellbeing index and Sleep hours in the dropdown

The Groups tab plot should update to show only selected groups and the chosen outcome on the y-axis.
 What does .data[[input$outcome]] do inside aes()?

title: Practical
section: Exercise 8: Build the Distributions tab plot with optional faceting
text:
Exercise 8: Build the Distributions tab plot with optional faceting
Now you’ll create a second plot for the Distributions tab. This plot will:

Use filtered_data() so it respects the group filter

Show the distribution of the selected outcome

Colour by participant_group

Optionally use facet_wrap(~ participant_group) when the checkbox is ticked

 Inside the server function, add another output called distribution_plot using renderPlot():
output$distribution_plot <- renderPlot({

  # Your code should have the following steps:
  #
  # A small if / else block at the top to set x_lab based on input$outcome
  #
  # Create a plot object named dist_plot that:
  # - Starts from filtered_data()  
  # - Pipes filtered_data() into ggplot()  
  # - Uses aes(x = .data[[input$outcome]])  
  # - Shows the distribution of the selected outcome using a histogram or density plot,
  #   with aes(fill = participant_group) to show overlapping distributions by group
  # - Uses labs(), custom colors/fills and theme layers
  #
  # A final line that is just dist_plot, to draw the plot


})
 Save app.R and click Run App. Try:

Checking and unchecking different participant groups in the sidebar

Switching between Wellbeing index and Sleep hours in the dropdown

Check that the Distributions tab responds as expected (it won’t yet respond to the “Show separate panels” checkbox - we’ll do that next).
 Now make your plot respond to the “Show separate panels” checkbox:

Go back inside the server function, after the code for the base plot
Add a little if(){...} block that checks the value of input$facet_by_group and if the value is TRUE, adds a facet_wrap() layer to the base plot to facet by participant_group


 Save app.R and click Run App. Try:

Ticking and unticking Show separate panels for each group


Now the Distributions tab should be fully functional.

title: Practical
text:
Exercise 9: Review, tidy, and reflect
In this final exercise, you’ll tidy your app and make sure you understand how each part works.
 In app.R, add a few short comments (lines starting with #) to remind your future self what each section does
 Looking back at your Week 9 app and this Week 10 dashboard, what are two key differences in how you structure and reuse code in Shiny?
You now have a multi-tab Shiny app that:

uses sidebarLayout() and tabsetPanel()

uses a reactive filtered dataset

efficiently looks up different outcome variables with .data[[input$outcome]]

and includes a tab-specific control for faceting

You can use any of these features in the final assessment.

title: Independent Study to Prepare
text: Read A checklist for designing and improving the visualization of scientific data

title: Week 1 Seminar: Principles of Data Visualisation
text:
About us
Instructor: Layla Unger

Students: Introductions

title: Week 1 Seminar: Principles of Data Visualisation
text:
Module objectives


Explore and understand datasets by visualising distributions, relationships, and trends.
Design clear and comprehensible visualisations that avoid common pitfalls.
Communicate findings to diverse audiences through compelling storytelling.
Build interactive dashboards that combine multiple visualisations.
Apply these skills across your degree and in a wide range of careers.

title: Week 1 Seminar: Principles of Data Visualisation
text:
Module organization

Explore
Explain


To accomplish these objectives, the module will be roughly divided into two parts.
In the first several weeks, we’ll discuss using visualizations to EXPLORE data.
So we’ll go through the main types of graph you can use to get a sense of the patterns in your data. So the focus here will be more on giving you tools to understand the data for yourself.
Then once you have a toolkit with lots of different kinds of graph, we’ll shift the focus to EXPLAINING data. So we’ll be seeing how to adapt the tools you’ve learned to make the patterns clear and compelling to an audience.

So, why visualize data?
At the start, you’ve got your pile of data. Lots of observations of maybe some things that have been measured out in the real world or in an experiment.
Typically there’ll be lots of numbers here, maybe some categorical variables etc.
On their own, the raw data don’t tell you anything.
NEXT
You can certainly gain some insight from summary statistics. Mean, SD, range.
NEXT

title: Week 1 Seminar: Principles of Data Visualisation
text:
Why visualise data?


Turn to a visual, and you immediately start seeing more.
This is something called a violin plot, with points added for individual data points [EXPLAIN]
This gives you both the sense that maybe the two groups differ, like the summary statistics.
BUT ALSO we can see outliers.

title: Week 1 Seminar: Principles of Data Visualisation
text:
Why visualise data?


We can enhance this further by adding lines to see trends in change over time, from pre to post.
Now we can see that in this main group of participants, symptom severity mostly goes down over time.
But those outliers are outliers not just in severity, but in lack of change.
And we can enhance this graph even further to get a sense of WHY those points are outliers.

title: Week 1 Seminar: Principles of Data Visualisation
text:
Why visualise data?


So here I’ve colored the points by the person who assessed the patients. And we can see that the outliers were all assessed by the same person.
Based on personal example.

title: Week 1 Seminar: Principles of Data Visualisation
text:
Why visualise data?


Finally, now that our exploration with visuals has revealed these outliers, we can do something about it.
We can regraph the data without the outliers. And now a clear trend pops out.

title: Week 1 Seminar: Principles of Data Visualisation
text:
Why visualise data?

To explore: find patterns, outliers, structure
To diagnose: check assumptions, spot problems
What else?


Explain to others

title: Week 1 Seminar: Principles of Data Visualisation
text:
Why visualise data?


Suppose we had a larger dataset from a big study we’ve run looking at effects of an intervention.
The quickest way to show our audience the effects of that intervention is probably a visual.
What does this graph tell us?

title: Week 1 Seminar: Principles of Data Visualisation
text:
Why visualise data?

To explore: find patterns, outliers, structure
To diagnose: check assumptions, spot problems
To explain: communicate results to others

Appropriate for the data
Focus attention on key points
Readable
Appealing



Transition - what do I mean by these things?

title: Week 1 Seminar: Principles of Data Visualisation
text:
What makes a good visualisation?

Appropriate for the data



What if we had this situation, wanted to look at change over time.
We could make different choices at this point - some would really help us see that change over time, others would make it difficult.

title: Week 1 Seminar: Principles of Data Visualisation
text:
What makes a good visualisation?

Appropriate for the data



We might choose to show this using bars.
But you might also be able to tell that the TOTAL NUMBER of students seems to increase.
So it’s hard to see here - is peer support getting more students because actually it’s getting more popular in comparison to the other options, or just because there are more students? Really can’t tell.

title: Week 1 Seminar: Principles of Data Visualisation

Appropriate for the data



Instead look at PROPORTIONS.
Flip back and forth.
SO NEED TO CHOOSE A VISUAL THAT IS APPROPRIATE FOR SHOWING KEY PATTERNS.

title: Overview
text:
This week you will get an introduction to why we visualise data and what makes a good visualisation. There will be a short paper to read to prepare and a seminar. There will be no practical this week!

Learning objectives
The successful student will be able to:

explain the multiple uses of data visualisations
explain the key aspects of an effective visualisation
evaluate whether a visualisation is good or bad

title: Data Visualisation
text:
This module introduces you to data visualisation in R.


The Module Learning outcomes are:

Explore and understand datasets by visualising distributions, relationships, and trends.
Design clear and comprehensible visualisations that avoid common pitfalls.
Communicate findings to diverse audiences through compelling storytelling.
Build interactive dashboards that combine multiple visualisations.
Apply these skills across your degree and in a wide range of careers.

title: Data Visualisation
text:
The Module Learning outcomes are:

Explore and understand datasets by visualising distributions, relationships, and trends.
Design clear and comprehensible visualisations that avoid common pitfalls.
Communicate findings to diverse audiences through compelling storytelling.
Build interactive dashboards that combine multiple visualisations.
Apply these skills across your degree and in a wide range of careers.

title: Data Visualisation
text:
Week 1: Principles of Data Visualisation
This week you will read a short paper about what makes a good visualization, and we will discuss this topic further in the seminar. There will be no practical.

title: Data Visualisation
text:
Week 2: Grammar of Graphics
This week you will be introduced to the fundamental tool for building visualizations in R: the grammar of graphics. We will discuss elements of the grammar of graphics in the seminar, and you will practice using it in the practical. In preparation for this week, you will start working through lessons on DataCamp on wrangling data in R using the tidyverse.

title: Data Visualisation
text:
Week 3: Distributions
This week, we will dive into how to plot the shape and range of variables in data. We will discuss common plots including histograms, density plots, boxplots and violin plots, and you will gain practice creating these graphs in the practical. You will also continue working through tidyverse lessons on DataCamp.

title: Data Visualisation
section: Week 4: Bar Plots for Categorical Data
text:
Week 4: Bar Plots for Categorical Data
This week, we will explore bar plots as a key tool for plotting characteristics of categorical data. We will discuss how to use bar plots to depict counts, proportions and summary statistics, and you will gain practice using bar plots in the practical.

title: Data Visualisation
text:
Week 5: Relationships between Variables
This week, we will examine relationships between variables. We will do a deep dive into scatterplots, adding trend lines, depicting how relationships differ across categorical groups, and correlation matrices. The practical will walk you through building these plots. To prepare for the following week, you will complete lessons on working with date and time variables on DataCamp.

title: Data Visualisation
section: Week 6: Time Series and Line Graphs
text:
Week 6: Time Series and Line Graphs
This week, we will explore how to visualise changes over time using line graphs. We will discuss how to de-clutter and emphasize temporal trends and work with date and time variables in the seminar, and you will practice depicting temporal data in the practical.

title: Data Visualisation
text:
Week 7: Advanced Customisation
Thus far, we have been exploring the different types of plots that can be used to illustrate different types of patterns. This week, we will transition customising the appearance of our plots for clarity and appeal. We will highlight several tools for improving plots including: customising and adding explanatory labels and annotations, formatting axes with appropriate breaks, effective use of color, reducing visual clutter, and combining multiple plots for comparison and synthesis.

title: Overview
text:
This week you will be introduced to Shiny apps. Shiny apps allow you to build dynamic web apps in which people can interactively explore visualisations.

Learning objectives
The successful student will be able to:

Explain what a Shiny app is and why we might use one
Recognise the anatomy of a Shiny app:

ui, server, shinyApp(ui, server)

Build a simple interactive app that:

Uses selectInput() and checkboxInput()
Updates a ggplot using renderPlot() and plotOutput()

Organise app.R and data files in a project structure

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
text:
From last week


The basic anatomy of a Shiny app:

ui, server, and shinyApp(ui, server)

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
text:
From last week


How to populate the UI with:

selectInput() to create a dropdown menu (chose a y-axis variable)
checkboxInput() to toggle a feature on/off (added points to a plot)
plotOutput() to define where the plot appears

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
text:
From last week


renderPlot() to create a plot output
How to use inputs in the server:

Used dropdown selection in if (...) { ... } else { ... } blocks to choose y-axis variable
Used checkbox selection in if (...) {} to add geom_point()

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
text:
Today

Inspect an updated app with new core features:

Give users more controls
Use these controls more efficiently “under the hood”

Learn how to implement the features in the ui and server

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
text:
Today

New UI features:

Sidebar layout (sidebarLayout(), sidebarPanel(), mainPanel())
A new input that filters data
Multiple tabs for different plots

New server features “under the hood”:

Reactive filtering with reactive()
Efficient use of user input in ggplot with .data[[input$outcome]]



Give a quick roadmap:

First, look at the finished Week 10 app and connect it to Week 9.
Then, focus on the new UI structure: sidebar vs main panel and tabs.
Finally, explore the server-side improvements: reactive filtering, .data[[...]], and the new checkbox that toggles faceting.

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
text:
Inspect an updated app

Key features:

Inputs are in a side panel, plots in a main panel
As in week 9, user choose which outcome to explore, but now users can also filter support levels: Low, Medium, High
Users can switch between two tabs to view the effects of support and therapy



Highlight the continuity:

Same dataset as before (therapy_df).
Same key variables: support_level, therapy, wellbeing, loneliness.
The new parts are about how we organise the UI and reuse code across multiple plots.

Emphasise the “dashboard” feel:

Instead of a single plot responding to inputs, we now have a mini dashboard:

multiple views,
shared controls, and
one plot-specific control (the facet checkbox).

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
text:
Today

New UI features

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
text:
New UI features: Overview

Today’s new UI concepts:

Splitting the page into a sidebar for inputs and a main panel for outputs
Including a UI input that filters data
Including multiple tabs in the main panel for different plots



This slide is just a preview.

We’ll first look at sidebar vs main panel.
Then we’ll see how to fill the sidebar with inputs.
Then we’ll look at how to add multiple tabs in the main panel.

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
text:
New UI features

Today’s new UI concepts:

Splitting the page into a sidebar for inputs and a main panel for outputs



Start with splitting the page into sidebar and main panel

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
text:
Sidebar and main panel

In Week 9, all UI elements lived directly inside fluidPage().

ui <- fluidPage(
  titlePanel("Wellbeing and Loneliness Dashboard"),

  p("Use the controls on the left to explore factors influencing wellbeing and loneliness."),

)

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
text:
Sidebar and main panel
We now add a layout function
ui <- fluidPage(
  titlePanel("Wellbeing and Loneliness Dashboard"),

  p("Use the controls on the left to explore factors influencing wellbeing and loneliness."),

  sidebarLayout(
   
  )
  
)

Tells shiny to use a layout with a sidebar and main panel

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
text:
Sidebar and main panel
We fill in the parts of the new layout
ui <- fluidPage(
  ...

  sidebarLayout(
    sidebarPanel(
      # inputs go here (e.g., dropdowns, checkboxes)
    ),
    mainPanel(
      # outputs go here (e.g., plots)
    )
  )
  
)

Key idea:

sidebarLayout() defines two regions:

sidebarPanel() – the left-hand column with inputs.
mainPanel() – the right-hand column with plots/output.


This makes the app feel more like a standard data dashboard.

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
text:
Filling in the sidebar
Pop in the same kinds of inputs from week 9
sidebarPanel(

  selectInput(
    inputId = "outcome", # name of the part in the input object
    label   = "Outcome to explore:", # label shown to the user
    choices = c(
      "Wellbeing score"  = "wellbeing_score",
      "Loneliness score" = "loneliness_score"
    ),
    selected = "wellbeing_score"
  )
)

Point out:

The dropdown (selectInput) is essentially identical to Week 9, but now lives inside the sidebar.

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
section: Filling in the sidebar: outcome dropdown
text:
Filling in the sidebar: outcome dropdown
Remember: this will store input$outcome as one of the two choice strings:
"wellbeing_score" or "loneliness_score"
selectInput(
  inputId = "outcome", 
  label   = "Outcome to explore:",
  choices = c(
    "Wellbeing score"  = "wellbeing_score",
    "Loneliness score" = "loneliness_score"
  ),
  selected = "wellbeing_score"
)

Remind students:

If the user chooses “Loneliness score”, then input$outcome becomes the string "loneliness_score".
We will later use this string to pick the correct column to plot.

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
text:
New UI features

Today’s new UI concepts:

Including a UI input that filters data

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
section: Filling in the sidebar: support-level checkboxes
text:
Filling in the sidebar: support-level checkboxes

New type of input: group of checkboxes
checkboxGroupInput(
  inputId  = "support_filter",
  label    = "Include support levels:",
  choices  = c("Low", "Medium", "High"),
  selected = c("Low", "Medium", "High")
)

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
section: Filling in the sidebar: support-level checkboxes
text:
Filling in the sidebar: support-level checkboxes

This will store input$support_filter as a vector of the user’s choices

If all checked: c("Low", "Medium", "High")
checkboxGroupInput(
  inputId  = "support_filter",
  label    = "Include support levels:",
  choices  = c("Low", "Medium", "High"),
  selected = c("Low", "Medium", "High")
)

Emphasise:

input$support_filter is a vector of strings:

Initially: c("Low", "Medium", "High").
If the user unchecks “Medium”, it becomes c("Low", "High").

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
section: Filling in the sidebar: support-level checkboxes
text:
Filling in the sidebar: support-level checkboxes

Later, vector of choices will be used to filter data in server
checkboxGroupInput(
  inputId  = "support_filter",
  label    = "Include support levels:",
  choices  = c("Low", "Medium", "High"),
  selected = c("Low", "Medium", "High")
)


Later in the server, we will use this vector to filter the dataset before plotting.

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
text:
New UI features

Today’s new UI concepts:

Including multiple tabs in the main panel for different output plots



Those were our new INPUT features.
Our UI also has this new output feature, where we’re now going to have different tabs for different output plots

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
section: Multiple tabs in the main panel
text:
Multiple tabs in the main panel
In week 9, we had a single output plot
Now we’ll show multiple plots in separate tabs
ui <- fluidPage(
  ...

  sidebarLayout(
    sidebarPanel(
      # inputs go here (e.g., dropdowns, checkboxes)
    ),
    mainPanel(
      # outputs go here (e.g., plots) <- Now MULTIPLE tabs!
    )
  )
  
)

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
section: Multiple tabs in the main panel
text:
Multiple tabs in the main panel
We’ll show multiple plots in separate tabs using tabsetPanel()
mainPanel(
  tabsetPanel(
    tabPanel(
      # tab title and contents
    ),
    tabPanel(
      # tab title and contents
    )
  )
)

Explain:

tabsetPanel() is a container that holds multiple tabPanel()s.
Each tabPanel():

Has a title.
Contains the outputs (and possibly inputs) specific to that tab.

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
section: Multiple tabs in the main panel
text:
Multiple tabs in the main panel
Zooming in on a single tab, Support:
tabPanel(
  title = "Support",
  plotOutput("support_plot") # just like our single output in week 9
)

Explain:

tabsetPanel() is a container that holds multiple tabPanel()s.
Each tabPanel():

Has a title.
Contains the outputs (and possibly inputs) specific to that tab.

plotOutput("support_plot"):

Space where Shiny will display the plot called output$support_plot from the server.

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
section: Multiple tabs in the main panel
text:
Multiple tabs in the main panel
Zooming in on a single tab, Therapy:
tabPanel(
  title = "Therapy",
  plotOutput("therapy_plot")
)

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
section: Multiple tabs in the main panel
text:
Multiple tabs in the main panel
Can add tab-specific input:
tabPanel(
  title = "Therapy",
  checkboxInput(
    inputId = "facet_by_support",
    label   = "Show breakdown by support level",
    value   = FALSE
  ),
  plotOutput("therapy_plot")
)

Key point:

Inputs can live in the sidebar (global) or inside individual tabs.
The facet_by_support checkbox only affects the Therapy tab plot, because only that server code reads input$facet_by_support.

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
text:
New server features: Overview

Reactive filtering with reactive()
Efficient use of user input in ggplot with .data[[input$outcome]]
Plot-specific user controls


This slide previews the three main server-side concepts:

A reactive filtered dataset.
Efficient variable lookup inside ggplot().
Using a checkbox to add/remove a facet layer.

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
text:
New server features

Reactive filtering with reactive()

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
text:
Reactive expressions: goal

Last week, we used all the data in the plot

Now:

Our input includes a group of checkboxes where users can select which support levels they want to see: Low, Medium, and/or High
We’ll use these checkboxes to filter which data points appear in the plots

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
text:
Reactive expressions: goal
Recall the sidebar checkboxes:
checkboxGroupInput(
  inputId  = "support_filter",
  label    = "Include support levels:",
  choices  = c("Low", "Medium", "High"),
  selected = c("Low", "Medium", "High")
)

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
text:
Reactive expressions: goal

Remember, user’s choices are stored in input$support_filter as a vector
Default vector is c("Low", "Medium", "High")
We can use this vector to do some familiar tidyverse wrangling:

therapy_df |>
  filter(support_level %in% input$support_filter)

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
text:
Reactive expressions: goal
Don’t want to repeat this filter for every one of our plots!
therapy_df |>
  filter(support_level %in% input$support_filter)

Highlight the problem:

Repeating the same filter code in multiple places is error-prone and harder to maintain.
If you ever change the filtering logic, you’d need to remember to update it everywhere.

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
section: Reactive expressions: re-use code as a function

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
section: Reactive expressions: re-use code as a function

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
section: Reactive expressions: why this is useful
text:
Reactive expressions: why this is useful

Why use reactive() here?

We only write the filter once
Any plot can use:

filtered_data() |>
  ggplot(...)

Connect to general programming principles:

This is an example of DRY (“Don’t Repeat Yourself”).
reactive() is Shiny’s way of letting you define reusable, reactive “helper functions” that depend on inputs.

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
text:
New server features

Efficient use of user input in ggplot with .data[[input$outcome]]

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
section: Efficiently referencing UI input in ggplot
text:
Efficiently referencing UI input in ggplot

Goal:

Use the outcome dropdown to choose which column goes on the ggplot y-axis, like Week 9
But avoid writing long if/else blocks to choose different ggplot code for each outcome

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
section: Efficiently referencing UI input in ggplot
text:
Efficiently referencing UI input in ggplot

Recall the dropdown menu:
selectInput(
  inputId = "outcome",
  label   = "Outcome to explore:",
  choices = c(
    "Wellbeing score"  = "wellbeing_score",
    "Loneliness score" = "loneliness_score"
  ),
  selected = "wellbeing_score"
)

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
section: Efficiently referencing UI input in ggplot
text:
Efficiently referencing UI input in ggplot


Remember, user’s choices are stored in input$outcome as string
Default string is "wellbeing_score" and can be switched to "loneliness_score"

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
section: Efficiently referencing UI input in ggplot

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
section: Efficiently referencing UI input in ggplot
text:
Efficiently referencing UI input in ggplot

Wouldn’t it be useful if we could avoid writing out the full ggplot with a different y-axis each time?

Why can’t we just do this?
ggplot(therapy_df, aes(y = input$outcome)) +
  ...

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
section: Efficiently referencing UI input in ggplot
text:
Efficiently referencing UI input in ggplot

Wouldn’t it be useful if we could avoid writing out the full ggplot with a different y-axis each time?

Why can’t we just do this?
ggplot(therapy_df, aes(y = input$outcome)) +
  ...
Would produce:
ggplot(therapy_df, aes(y = "wellbeing_score")) + # note the quotes
  ...

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
section: Efficiently referencing UI input in ggplot
text:
Efficiently referencing UI input in ggplot

ggplot needs to interpret arguments of aes() as variables, not strings

Inside ggplot, we can use .data[[...]]:
filtered_data() |>
  ggplot(aes(
    x    = support_level,
    y    = .data[[input$outcome]], 
    fill = support_level
  )) +
  ...
Read as: “Use the column whose name is given by this string.”

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
section: Efficiently referencing UI input in ggplot
text:
Efficiently referencing UI input in ggplot

So:

If input$outcome == "wellbeing_score":

.data[[input$outcome]] → the wellbeing_score column.

If input$outcome == "loneliness_score":

.data[[input$outcome]] → the loneliness_score column.


No need for long if\else blocks

Key advantage:

We can write one ggplot call and have it automatically adjust to whichever outcome the user selects.
No need to duplicate the entire ggplot code in if/else blocks.

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
section: Efficiently referencing UI input in ggplot

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
text:
New server features

Plot-specific user controls

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
text:
Plot-specific UI controls: revisiting Week 9

In Week 9, we used a checkbox to optionally add a layer:
# In ui:
checkboxInput(
  inputId = "show_points",
  label   = "Show individual data points",
  value   = FALSE
)

# In server:
output_plot <- ...

if (input$show_points) {
  output_plot <- output_plot +
    geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.1), alpha = 0.4)
}

output_plot

Remind them:

This was their first example of a plot-specific control that toggles a feature on and off.
The pattern was:

Build a base plot,
Then conditionally add a layer if a checkbox is TRUE.

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
text:
Plot-specific UI controls: facet on/off

In Week 10, we use the same pattern in the Therapy tab:
# In ui:
checkboxInput(
  inputId = "facet_by_support",
  label   = "Show breakdown by support level",
  value   = FALSE
)

# In server:
therapy_plot <- ...

if (input$facet_by_support) {
  therapy_plot <- therapy_plot + facet_wrap(~ support_level)
}

therapy_plot

Emphasise the parallel:

Instead of toggling a geom_point layer, we’re now toggling a facet_wrap layer.
The logic is the same:

Build a base plot.
Check the checkbox value.
If TRUE, add an extra feature (facets).

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
text:
Summary
Today we:

Introduced new UI features:

sidebarLayout(), sidebarPanel(), mainPanel()
A support-level filter based on checkboxGroupInput()
Multiple tabs using tabsetPanel() and tabPanel()

title: Week 10 Seminar: Shiny Apps 2
text:
Summary
Today we:

Introduced new server features:

Re-usable data filter using a reactive() expression
Efficient use of the outcome input via .data[[input$outcome]] in ggplot()
A tab-specific checkbox that toggles facet_wrap(~ support_level) in the Therapy plot



Close the loop:

Emphasise that the Week 10 app is a model for their final assessment:

Multiple views of the same data.
Shared inputs.
Possibly one or two plot-specific controls.

Encourage them to think: “How could I adapt this pattern to my own dataset?”

title: Practical
text:
In this introduction you will start working with RStudio. You will read in a dataset and plot the data it contains in various ways.

Practicals are not a test. It is expected that you often don’t know how to start, make a lot of mistakes and need help. It is expected that you are familiar with independent study content before the workshop. However, you need not remember or understand every detail as the workshop should build and consolidate your understanding. Tips

don’t worry about making mistakes
don’t let what you can not do interfere with what you can do
discussing code with your neighbours will help
look things up in the independent study material
look things up in your own code from earlier workshops
there are no stupid questions







Key



These four symbols are used at the beginning of each instruction so you know where to carry out the instruction.
 Something you need to do on your computer. It may be opening programs or documents or locating a file.
 Something you should do in RStudio. It will often be typing a command or using the menus but might also be creating folders, locating or moving files.
 Something you should do in your browser on the internet. It may be searching for information, going to the VLE or downloading a file.
 A question for you to think about and answer. Record your answers in your script for future reference.

Key



These four symbols are used at the beginning of each instruction so you know where to carry out the instruction.
 Something you need to do on your computer. It may be opening programs or documents or locating a file.
 Something you should do in RStudio. It will often be typing a command or using the menus but might also be creating folders, locating or moving files.
