 A question for you to think about and answer. Record your answers in your script for future reference.

title: Practical
text:
Wellbeing
We’ll be working with a simulated dataset is based on a fictional cross-sectional survey study exploring the relationships between social support, therapy attendance, loneliness, sleep quality, and overall wellbeing in adults.
In this fictional study, participants were recruited from community mental health clinics and general community advertisements between 2019 and 2022. They completed a survey assessing:

Perceived social support (categorized as Low, Medium, or High)
Current therapy status (Yes or No)
Loneliness (a standardized loneliness score; higher scores indicate greater loneliness)
Subjective wellbeing (higher scores indicate better wellbeing)
Sleep quality (rated on a 1–10 scale)
Demographics, including age and sex

The fictional study aimed to understand how social support and therapy might relate to feelings of loneliness and overall wellbeing, as well as how these factors interact with sleep and demographic characteristics.

title: Practical
text:
Packages
Commands like c(), sum(), and str() are in packages which are part the ‘base’ R system. A package is a collection of related commands. Base packages are installed automatically when you install R.
Other packages, such as ggplot2 (Wickham 2016) need to be installed once and then loaded each session. ggplot2 is one of the tidyverse (Wickham et al. 2019) packages.






Important



If you are working on a University computer (or the VDS) you do not need to install tidyverse.
If you are working on your own computer or using RStudio cloud you do need to install tidyverse.


To install a package:
 Go the Packages tab on the lower right pane. Click Install and type tidyverse into the box that appears.
Wait until you get the prompt back. It will take a few moments, be patient!
To use a package which is installed you have to load it with the library() function. You will need to do this whether you are working on your own computer or on a University computer
 Load the tidyverse. Type or copy the following code into your R script:

library(tidyverse)

 Ensure your cursor is on the line with the code you just added and hit Ctrl+Enter to run it.
You can follow this same step to run any code you add to your R script!
You will likely be warned of some function name conflicts but these will not be a problem for you.

title: Practical
text:
Reading in data
You will go into more depth about reading in data in the Data Analysis module. For now, you can just follow these steps.
 Save this file in your week-2 folder:

Data from fictional wellbeing study: therapy_data.csv


 Add the following code to your R script and run:

therapy_df <- read_csv("therapy_data.csv")

title: Practical
text:
Look at data
 Examine the variables and first few rows of the therapy_df object using head()

head(therapy_df)

# A tibble: 6 × 8
  support_level therapy   age loneliness_score wellbeing_score sleep_quality
  <chr>         <chr>   <dbl>            <dbl>           <dbl>         <dbl>
1 Medium        No         42             30.4            58.6             6
2 Low           Yes        23             72.2            44.5             6
3 Low           No         35             47.1            39.8             7
4 Medium        No         23             35.1            56.8             8
5 Medium        Yes        20             57.0            60.6             6
6 Medium        No         40             47.2            61.5             6
# ℹ 2 more variables: sex <chr>, year <dbl>


See that you have a table where each column is a variable from the fictional study, such as wellbeing_score. Each row contains values for each variable for one participant.

title: Practical
text:
Exercise 1: Distributions
Look at the distribution of the main outcome variable, the wellbeing score.
 Plot the distribution by creating a plot in which the x-axis variable is wellbeing_score and the distribution of this variable is shown as a histogram.

ggplot(therapy_df, aes(x = wellbeing_score)) +
  geom_histogram()







Any geom has multiple attributes, such as color. When you just specify the geom followed by empty brackets, like geom_histogram(), the values for those attributes are chosen by default. This means that, under the hood, geom_histogram() is setting the fill of the bars to a gray color, like this:

ggplot(therapy_df, aes(x = wellbeing_score)) +
  geom_histogram(fill = "#525252")







Similarly, geom_histogram() chooses the number “bins” that group together values within the same bar.
For this dataset, the default is 30 bins. So the code above is the same as the code below and produces the same histogram:

ggplot(therapy_df, aes(x = wellbeing_score)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 30)







But, we can change these defaults.
 Try setting the bins to a larger or smaller number than 30 and see what happens.

title: Practical
text:
Exercise 2: Comparing distributions in groups
What if we want to see the distribution of wellbeing_score for different groups of people, such as people with different levels of support? We can do this using a boxplot.
 Create a boxplot:

ggplot(therapy_df, aes(x = support_level, y = wellbeing_score)) +
  geom_boxplot()







Just like geom_histogram(), geom_boxplot() is actually setting values for attributes like fill to a default value. As you can see, the boxes are filled in white.
 Try changing the fill to a different color, like “red”.
See Exercise 1 above for an example of setting the fill color to a value (above the color was a hex string: “#525252”, but here you can change it to the name of a common color, like “red” )
 Change the fill color
Now, instead of setting all boxes to the same color, we can use a variable to control the fill aesthetic.
 Try using the support_level variable to control the fill aesthetic.
You will still modify the content inside the brackets for geom_boxplot(), but now instead of fill = "color_name", you’ll need to use aes(fill = name_of_variable).
 Once you’ve used the suport_level variable to control the fill aesthetic, you can add a line to choose specific fill colors for each support_level. Copy your code above, add a + at the end of the last line, and add this line:

scale_fill_manual(values = c("red", "blue", "purple"))

 Try a violin plot instead using geom_violin(). what differences do you see?

title: Practical
section: Exercise 3: Visualising summaries with bar plots
text:
Exercise 3: Visualising summaries with bar plots
Instead of looking at the whole distribution of wellbeing_scores for each support level, maybe we just want to look at a summary statistic, like the mean values.
We can generate a new dataset that contains just mean values of wellbeing_scores for each support_level.
 Run the following code to generate the new summary dataset:

therapy_summary <- therapy_df %>%
  group_by(support_level) %>%
  summarise(wellbeing_score_mean = mean(wellbeing_score))

Use the therapy_summary data to create a barplot that depicts the mean wellbeing scores (on the y-axis) for each support level (x-axis) using geom_bar().
 Remember that within the brackets for geom_bar(), you need to specify stat = "identity" so that it uses the y-axis variable you specified.
 Change the bar colors to custom colors you choose using scale_fill_manual()
Check the seminar slides for examples of using manual scales!

title: Practical
text:
Exercise 4: Relationships between continuous variables
What if we want to look at relationships between continuous variables, such as loneliness_score and wellbeing_score?
 We can create a scatterplot, like this:

ggplot(therapy_df, aes(x = loneliness_score, y = wellbeing_score)) +
  geom_point()







 Modify the code above to use the support_level variable to control the color and shape aesthetics of geom_point()

title: Practical
text:
Exercise 5: Coordinate system adjustments
 Take the bar plot from Exercise 3 and flip the coordinates to horizontal bars using coord_flip()
 Try using coord_cartesian() to limit the y-axis range to focus on a particular range (e.g., ylim = c(40, 80))

title: Practical
text:
Exercise 7: Faceting
 Copy the same scatterplot of loneliness_score vs wellbeing_score from Exercise 4

ggplot(therapy_df, aes(x = loneliness_score, y = wellbeing_score)) +
  geom_point()







 Add a facet_wrap() line to create separate facets for each value of the support_level variable

ggplot(therapy_df, aes(x = loneliness_score, y = wellbeing_score)) +
  geom_point() +
  facet_wrap(~ support_level)







You’re finished!

title: Overview
text:
This week you will get a brief review of data management in R, then an in-depth walkthrough of the many ways to visualise distributions. There is a preparation step to get acquainted with standard data management in R.

Learning objectives
The successful student will be able to:

generate various types of plot to visualise distributions
overlay multiple plots to provide more visual information about distributions
customise the appearance of distribution plots (e.g., colors)
perform some basic data wrangling to prepare data for visualisation

title: Week 3 Seminar: Distributions
text:
From last time

Using grammar of graphics:

mapping data variables to axes, shapes (bars, points, etc)
controlling attributes such as color, coordinate ranges
customising appearance
faceting

10 Depression           43.5  24.2         1.80           8.95

generate additional variables by group


psych_df %>% 
  group_by(diagnosis) %>%
  mutate(stress_diagnosis = mean(stress_score)) %>%
  select(diagnosis, stress_score, stress_diagnosis)

generate additional variables by group

title: Week 3 Seminar: Distributions
text:
Useful functions: ifelse
generate additional variables by group


psych_df %>% 
  group_by(diagnosis) %>%
  mutate(stress_diagnosis = mean(stress_score),
         stress_binary = ifelse(stress_score > stress_diagnosis, "high", "typical"))%>%
  select(diagnosis, stress_score, stress_diagnosis, stress_binary)

# A tibble: 300 × 4
# Groups:   diagnosis [3]
   diagnosis  stress_score stress_diagnosis stress_binary
   <fct>             <dbl>            <dbl> <chr>

 4 None              17.4              16.5 high         
 5 None              19.7              16.5 high         
 6 Anxiety           26.0              30.4 typical

10 Depression        34.0              28.3 high         
# ℹ 290 more rows

title: Week 3 Seminar: Distributions
text:
Useful functions: group_by + summarise
calculating summaries for groups


psych_df %>% 
  group_by(diagnosis) %>% 
  summarise(stress_mean = mean(stress_score))

# A tibble: 3 × 2
  diagnosis  stress_mean
  <fct>            <dbl>
1 None              16.5
2 Anxiety           30.4
3 Depression        28.3

title: Week 3 Seminar: Distributions
text:
Other useful data wrangling functions

arrange() sorts data

rename() does exactly what you think

left_join() (and other joins) combines datasets based on shared values in shared variables

title: Week 3 Seminar: Distributions
text:
Today

Tidyverse overview

Graphing distributions: techniques and considerations

histograms
density plots
boxplots
violin plots
ridgeline plots

title: Week 3 Seminar: Distributions
text:
Why distributions?


Distributions show the overall shape and spread of data that single summary statistics (like the mean) can miss



Help spot skew and outliers, which inform choices of appropriate analyses

title: Week 3 Seminar: Distributions
text:
Visualizing distributions

Focus on visualizing the distribution of one variable:
stress_score

Pros/cons of different ways to visualize and compare distributions

1. Histograms

Visualize the distribution of a numeric variable with lots of values

Pro:

can view the entire distribution

Con:

need to be careful with bin width

title: Week 3 Seminar: Distributions
text:
1. Histograms

psych_df %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = stress_score)) +
  geom_histogram()



Note - in previous lectures, when I was setting up the lectures, I put in some code that you couldn’t see that customized the appearance of the plots, such as the text size, background color, etc. But from now on we’re going to be looking closely at the code for generating plots, so I’ve only done minimal formatting to make sure that the font size is visible and the background is plain.

title: Week 3 Seminar: Distributions
text:
2. Density plots

Smoothed version of the histogram
Pro:

Focus on overall shape rather than local fluctuations

Con:

Can be misleading with small data sets

title: Week 3 Seminar: Distributions
text:
2. Density plots

psych_df %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = stress_score)) +
  geom_density()

title: Week 3 Seminar: Distributions

2. Density plots

  ggplot(aes(x = stress_score)) +
  geom_density(fill = "blue", `alpha` = 0.75)

title: Week 3 Seminar: Distributions
text:
2. Density plots
overlaying a histogram

psych_df %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = stress_score, y = after_stat(density))) +
  # the y argument scales down the histogram 
  # to match the density curve
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 1, fill = "blue", 
                 color = "black", alpha = 0.75) +
  geom_density()

title: Week 3 Seminar: Distributions

comparing multiple distributions

  ggplot(aes(x = stress_score, fill = diagnosis)) +
  geom_density(alpha = 0.4)

title: Week 3 Seminar: Distributions
text:
2. Density plots



NOTICE: when we used a variable to set the fill color, ggplot chose the color SCALE automatically.
It uses this default color scale.

title: Week 3 Seminar: Distributions
text:
2. Density plots
comparing multiple distributions

psych_df %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = stress_score, fill = diagnosis)) +
  geom_density(alpha = 0.5) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("gray", "lightyellow", "lightblue")) +
  theme_bw()

title: Week 3 Seminar: Distributions
text:
2. Density plots



We can override these colors manually by adding a scale layer.

title: Week 3 Seminar: Distributions
text:
2. Density plots

psych_df %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = stress_score)) +
  geom_density(fill = "blue", alpha = 0.5) +
  facet_wrap(~diagnosis)


But this example also highlights an issue here. We want to see those distributions, but the overlap makes that difficult
So instead of filling them with different colors, we could split them across different facets.

title: Week 3 Seminar: Distributions
text:
3. Box plots
Compact depiction of:

Median, 25/75 percentiles (quartiles)
Potential outliers

Pro:

Conveys key aspects of distribution in a concise way

Con:

Can’t see full distribution, which may obscure characteristics such as multi-modality

title: Week 3 Seminar: Distributions
text:

psych_df %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = diagnosis, y = stress_score)) +
  geom_boxplot()

  ggplot(aes(x = diagnosis, y = stress_score)) +
  geom_boxplot(fill = "gray", outlier.color = "blue", 
               outlier.shape = "circle open", outlier.size = 2)

5. Ridgeline plots

Like violin plots, depict distributions of a variable for multiple groups
Distributions are depicted as densities or histograms rather than violins

Requires the ggridges package
An extension of ggplot2 that uses the same syntax

Summary: Distributions
What you’re showing:

Shape (range, skew, modality)
Centre (median/mean)
Spread (e.g., interquartile range)
Outliers

title: Week 3 Seminar: Distributions
text:
Summary: Distributions
Pick the display

Histogram – whole shape, aggregated in bins
Density – smooth shape
Boxplot – compact summary (median, quartiles)
Violin – smooth shapes for groups, can add points
Ridgeline – smooth shapes for groups

title: Independent Study to Prepare
text:
Preparation for Weeks 2 and 3: Get Acquainted with Tidy Data Wrangling
This preparation involves reading some chapters in an online book and getting started with an online DataCamp course. I will recommend this preparation for weeks 2 and 3. You can try taking an initial look in week 2, and revisit the reading more deeply in week 3.
Although the focus of this module is on data visualisation, before you visualise data, you often need to take some steps to get it into a form that you can visualise. These steps are often referred to using phrases like “data management” and “data wrangling”. These days, it is common practice in R to perform steps to ensure that your data are in a standard, “tidy” format in which data are stored in a table where each row is an observation and each column is a variable. Common steps for preparing data for visualisation and analysis include:

Generating summary statistics, such as the mean value of an outcome variable for groups of participants
Selecting a subset of data, such as a subset of variables, or rows for just participants in a subset of groups

The Data Analysis module that you will be completing at the same time will cover many common tidy data wrangling steps, particularly in Weeks 3 and 4. Therefore, we won’t spend much time covering these steps in the seminars for Data Visualisation. However, since this is a crucial part of working with data in R, you will benefit from getting acquainted with it for this module as well.
There are many resources for learning about tidy data wrangling. You are encouraged to try the following two resources:

Read Tidyverse Ch 4 - 7
DataCamp courses on tidyverse and tidy wrangling:

Introduction to the Tidyverse
Categorical Data in the Tidyverse
Reshaping Data with tidyr




Distributions
To prepare for diving into this week’s topic, visualising distributions:

Read Data Visualization Ch 7 and 9

title: Practical
text:
In this practical you will read in a dataset and create bar plots of counts, proportions, and summary statistics. You will also get a bit more practice with tidyverse data wrangling.

Practicals are not a test. It is expected that you often don’t know how to start, make a lot of mistakes and need help. It is expected that you are familiar with independent study content before the workshop. However, you need not remember or understand every detail as the workshop should build and consolidate your understanding. Tips

don’t worry about making mistakes
don’t let what you can not do interfere with what you can do
discussing code with your neighbours will help
look things up in the independent study material
look things up in your own code from earlier workshops
there are no stupid questions







Key



These four symbols are used at the beginning of each instruction so you know where to carry out the instruction.
 Something you need to do on your computer. It may be opening programs or documents or locating a file.
 Something you should do in RStudio. It will often be typing a command or using the menus but might also be creating folders, locating or moving files.
 Something you should do in your browser on the internet. It may be searching for information, going to the VLE or downloading a file.
 A question for you to think about and answer. Record your answers in your script for future reference.

title: Practical
text:
Learning app engagement
We’ll be working with a simulated dataset from a fictional digital learning app. Users belong to different user_segments who arrive via different acquisition channels and use the app on mobile or desktop. We’ll look at how engagement differs across different groups.
Variables:


user_segment: categorical (Students, EarlyCareer, MidCareer, Senior)


device_type: categorical (Mobile, Desktop)


acquisition_channel: categorical (Organic, Ads, Referral, Email)


product_engagement: continuous (0–100 engagement score combining use frequency, session time, and lessons completed)

title: Practical
text:
Packages
Remember that packages, such as ggplot2 (part of tidyverse) need to be installed once and then loaded each session.
Today we’ll use tidyverse.






Important



If you are working on a University computer (or the VDS) you do not need to install tidyverse.
If you are working on your own computer or using RStudio cloud you do need to install tidyverse.


To install a package:
 Go the Packages tab on the lower right pane. Click Install and type the name of the package into the box that appears.
To use a package which is installed you have to load it with the library() function.
 Load the tidyverse. Type or copy the following code into your R script:

library(tidyverse)

title: Practical
text:
Reading in data
 Save this file in your week-4 folder:

App engagement data: app_engagement.csv


 Add the following code to your R script and run:

app_df <- read_csv("app_engagement.csv")

title: Practical
text:
Look at data
 Examine the variables and first few rows of the app_df object using head().

head(app_df)

# A tibble: 6 × 5
  user_id user_segment device_type acquisition_channel product_engagement
    <dbl> <chr>        <chr>       <chr>                            <dbl>
1       1 MidCareer    Mobile      Organic                           55.8
2       2 EarlyCareer  Desktop     Organic                           89.9
3       3 Students     Desktop     Organic                           40.6
4       4 Senior       Mobile      Organic                           48.7
5       5 MidCareer    Mobile      Ads                               51.1
6       6 Students     Mobile      Referral                          79.1


See that each column is a variable (e.g., product_engagement), and each row is one user.

title: Practical
text:
Reorder the values of product_engagement

In R, categorical variables are often treated as a special type of variable called a “factor”.
In factors, the different values of the variable are called “levels”.
By default, the order of the levels is alphabetical.
We have discussed reordering the levels of a factor based on values of another variable. But, we can also manually specify an order that is appropriate for our data.
In this dataset, user_segment is a factor with a natural order from junior to senior: Students, EarlyCareer, MidCareer, Senior.
 Reorder the levels of user_segement.

app_df <- app_df %>%
  mutate(user_segment = factor(user_segment, levels = c("Students", "EarlyCareer","MidCareer", "Senior")))

title: Practical
text:
Exercise 1: Bar plot of counts

Look at how many users are in each user_segment.
 Create a basic bar plot of counts of users in each user_segment (remember: counts are the default stat of geom_bar() and therefore stat does not need to be explicitly specified):








 Order the bars by frequency using forcats::fct_infreq() on user_segment inside aes():








 Where does geom_bar() get the heights from?

title: Practical
section: Exercise 2: Split counts by a second variable
text:
Exercise 2: Split counts by a second variable
We can split counts by acquisition_channel.
 Stack counts by acquisition_channel using aes(fill = acquisition_channel)):








 Unstack to compare absolute counts side-by-side using position = "dodge":








 When might stacked vs dodged bars be preferable?

title: Practical
text:
Exercise 3: Proportions (100% stacked)

For comparing composition across groups, use proportions.
 Convert to proportions with position = "fill". Remember to rename the y-axis variable:








 Why are proportions sometimes more informative than raw counts?

title: Practical
text:
Exercise 4: Wrangling equivalent for proportions
Instead of letting geom_bar() do the counting, compute counts yourself first.
 Use count() and mutate() to compute group-wise proportions:

title: Practical
section: Exercise 5: Summary bar (mean engagement by segment)
text:
Exercise 5: Summary bar (mean engagement by segment)
Now let’s summarise a continuous variable by category: mean product_engagement (y-axis) per user_segment (x-axis).
 Use stat_summary() to plot means with SE bars (for means, fun = "mean", and for SE, fun.data = "mean_se"):








 Colour the bars by user_segment (optional: set show.legend = FALSE to reduce redundancy):

title: Practical
section: Exercise 6: Wrangling equivalent for summary bars
text:
Exercise 6: Wrangling equivalent for summary bars
Compute mean and SE yourself, then plot with geom_bar(stat = "identity").
Reminder: SE = sd(variable) / sqrt(n())
 Use summarise to calculate mean_eng and se_eng, then use the summarised data in a plot that uses geom_bar() and geom_linerange() instead of stat_summary(). Remember that geom_bar() needs stat = "identity" to override the default stat = "count".








 What are the pros/cons of using stat_summary() vs pre-computing with summarise()?

title: Practical
text:
Exercise 7: Grouped summary bars (two-way comparison)
Compare mean engagement across user_segment and device_type.
You can reuse and adapt the code you wrote for Exercise 5 that used stat_summary() to create this plot.
 Keep user_segment as your x-axis variable, but add device_type as the fill aes() for the bars and the group aes() for the linerange error bars. Remember to dodge your bars and error bars.








 Describe the pattern you see. For which user segment(s) does Mobile outperform Desktop, and where is Desktop higher?
You’re finished!

title: Independent Study to Consolidate
text:
Exercise 1: Bar plot of counts
 Create a bar plot showing how many participants are in each diagnosis group.
Reflect: Which diagnosis group has the largest number of participants?

title: Independent Study to Consolidate
text:
Exercise 2: Stacked bar plot
 Make a stacked bar plot of diagnosis by sex.
Then, re-plot using position = "dodge".
Reflect: When is the stacked version more informative, and when is the dodged version clearer?

title: Independent Study to Consolidate
text:
Exercise 3: Proportions
 Create a stacked barplot of proportions for sex (position = "fill") within each diagnosis. Remember to label the y-axis appropriately.
Reflect: What does this plot tell you that the count plots do not?

title: Independent Study to Consolidate
text:
Exercise 4: Wrangling equivalent
 Use count() and mutate() to calculate proportions of sex within each diagnosis. Plot the proportions using geom_bar(stat = "identity").

title: Independent Study to Consolidate
text:
Exercise 5: Summary bar plot
 Plot the mean stress_score (y-axis) for each diagnosis group (x-axis) with error bars showing standard error.

title: Independent Study to Consolidate
text:
Exercise 6: Grouped summary bar plot
 Create a grouped bar plot comparing mean stress_score across both diagnosis (x-axis) and sex (fill).
Add error bars for standard error and make sure bars and error bars are aligned by using position_dodge().

title: Overview
text:
This week you will learn how to visualise relationships between continuous variables. We will cover scatterplots, trend lines, visualising how relationships differ between groups, and correlation matrices. Within these topics, we will cover joining multiple related datasets together.

Learning objectives
The successful student will be able to:

generate scatterplots to show relationships between continuous variables
add trend lines to highlight the direction of the relationship
split scatterplots by categorical groups using color and facets
plot correlation matrices
join relational data based on shared identifiers

title: Week 5 Seminar: Relationships between Variables
text:
From last time

Bar plots:

counts, proportions, summary bars with error bars


Last week we focused on using bar plots to get insight into CATEGORICAL variables. We looked at how to count up the number of observations in categorical groups and proportions. We also looked at visualizing how a continuous variable differed across categorical groups.
We did this by using bars to convey summary statistics for each group, like using the height of the bar to show the mean value of a continuous variable in each group.

title: Week 5 Seminar: Relationships between Variables
section: Why plot relationships between continuous variables?
text:
Why plot relationships between continuous variables?


See how changes in one variable are associated with changes in another
See how relationships between continuous variables differ across categorical groups
Displays the patterns analyzed in correlations, regression







employee_id
job_role
training_hours
client_contacts
task_switch_hours
performance_index




E0001
account_manager
6.1
9.47
9.0
49.7


E0002
support_engineer
6.1
6.41
5.9
71.3


E0003
implement_specialist
7.0
4.27
5.0
66.8








We have continuous variables here like number of training hours and the employee’s perfrmance index.
Are they positively related? Does more training improve performance?
We also have task switch hours. How does that relate to performance? Is it negatively related?
We also have a categorical variable here, job role. Do relationships between those variables differ across groups? Maybe training helps performance for some roles but less for others.
These are the kinds of questions we’d analyze using correlations and regression. So we want to visualize these patterns to see what our analyses are capturing.

title: Week 5 Seminar: Relationships between Variables
text:
Today


Scatterplots in depth
Adding trend lines
Differences across categorical groups
Correlation matrices

Will include:

Joining relational data


Today we’re going to focus on plots that show us relationships between continuous variables. The primary way to depict these relationships is scatterplots, so we’ll be talking about those in depth.
We’ll also talk about how to add lines to really emphasize the core relationship between variables.
And finally we’ll cover plots that visualize multiple relationships at once, in correlation matrices.
As we’re doing this, I’m going to show you how we can join multiple related datasets.

title: Week 5 Seminar: Relationships between Variables
section: Why plot relationships between continuous variables?
text:
Why plot relationships between continuous variables?

See how changes in one variable are associated with changes in another
See how relationships between continuous variables differ across categorical groups
Displays the patterns analyzed in correlations, regression

title: Week 5 Seminar: Relationships between Variables
text:
Scatter Plot: Basic
relationship between x and y

ggplot(customer_ops, aes(x = training_hours, y = performance_index)) 



We want to look at relationships between two variables here.
So we treat one as the x variable and the other as the y

title: Week 5 Seminar: Relationships between Variables
text:
Scatter Plot: Basic
relationship betwen x and y: geom_point

ggplot(customer_ops, aes(x = training_hours, y = performance_index)) +
  geom_point()



Then to see how they’re related, we just add a point for each employee.
Already gives us a basic sense of this positive relationship.
BUT there are many things we might want to do to adapt this basic plot approach to make it more readable.

title: Week 5 Seminar: Relationships between Variables
text:
Scatter Plot: Improve Readability
transparency (alpha)

ggplot(customer_ops, aes(training_hours, performance_index)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5)

title: Week 5 Seminar: Relationships between Variables
text:
Scatter Plot: Improve Readability
transparency (alpha)


First, we don’t actually care hugely about those individual points. We want to see the relationship between variables. SO we can emphasize with making points transparent.

Go back to previous plot - note that most people’s training hours were a little different from other people’s, so there weren’t lots of overlapping points with the same training hours.
But what if there was more overlap? Here’s the data again, but with one change - now hours is rounded to the nearest whole hour. So now it’s more likely that different people will have the same number of training hours.

text:
Scatter Plot: Improve Readability
many points hard to see

ggplot(customer_ops_big, aes(training_hours, performance_index)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.1)



What if we had a whole lot more data? Now even with transparency this plot is kind of busy.

title: Week 5 Seminar: Relationships between Variables
text:
Scatter Plot: Improve Readability
many points hard to see: combine in bins

ggplot(customer_ops_big, aes(training_hours, performance_index)) +
  geom_hex(bins = 20)

title: Week 5 Seminar: Relationships between Variables
text:
Scatter Plot: Improve Readability
many points hard to see: combine in bins


One way to overcome this is to group points with similar x- and y-values into bins.
This is similar to the histograms we saw back when talking about distributions.
There, we just binned similar values on ONE dimension into bins.
Here, this plot bins points with similar values on TWO dimensions into bins.
ALSO NOTE: ggplot autmatically gave us this color gradient to indicate how many points are in a bin.
So lighter blue indicates that more points are in the bin.

title: Week 5 Seminar: Relationships between Variables
text:
Scatter Plot: Improve Readability
many points hard to see: combine in bins

ggplot(customer_ops_big, aes(training_hours, performance_index)) +
  geom_hex(bins = 20) +
  scale_fill_gradient(low = "grey90", high = "grey20") #<

title: Week 5 Seminar: Relationships between Variables
text:
Scatter Plot: Improve Readability
many points hard to see: combine in bins


And just as a reminder, we can always override those color choices manually.

title: Week 5 Seminar: Relationships between Variables
text:
Scatter Plot: Add Distributions
distribution of each variable

ggplot(customer_ops, aes(training_hours, performance_index)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.4)



Going back to this basic plot - we can see here the relationship between the two variables, but what if we also wanted to look at the distribution of each one?
We can kind of try do do this ourselves - just look visually at distribution along x-axis and distribution along y-axis. But it’s hard, the relationship is emphasized.
It would be possible to have separate plots of distributions.
PROMPT: can people remember types of distribution plots???

title: Week 5 Seminar: Relationships between Variables
text:
Scatter Plot: Add Distributions
distribution of each variable

library(ggExtra)

p <- ggplot(customer_ops, aes(training_hours, performance_index)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.4) #< store the plot

ggMarginal(p, type = "histogram") #< add histograms

title: Week 5 Seminar: Relationships between Variables
text:
Scatter Plot: Trend Lines
display relationship as a line


Going back to this basic scatterplot.
We see this cloud of points. And we can kind of see the relationship - roughly as switch ours increase, performance decreases. It looks like a negative relationship.
But we have to do the work of squinting and seeing that ourselves.
We can make it easier by adding a best fit line.
PROMPT: can anyone think back to analysis techniques, and think of what the analysis is called when we try to fit a line that captures the relationship between two variables?
REGRESSION WHEN BETWEEN TWO VARIABLES, SAME AS CORRELATION
WE COULD fit a regression model, extract the line, and add it to the plot…

title: Week 5 Seminar: Relationships between Variables
text:
Scatter Plot: Trend Lines
display relationship as a line

ggplot(customer_ops, aes(task_switch_hours, performance_index)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm") #< add a line using "linear model" regression



But ggplot has built-in functions for fitting lines to data.

title: Week 5 Seminar: Relationships between Variables
text:
Scatter Plot: Trend Lines
bonus: add statistic

library(ggpubr)


ggplot(customer_ops, aes(task_switch_hours, performance_index)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm") + #< add a line using "linear model" regression
  stat_cor()

title: Week 5 Seminar: Relationships between Variables
text:
Scatter Plot: Trend Lines
bonus: add statistic


Package ggpubr extends functionality of ggplot and allows you to add a stat layer with correlation stat

title: Week 5 Seminar: Relationships between Variables
section: Why plot relationships between continuous variables?
text:
Why plot relationships between continuous variables?

See how changes in one variable are associated with changes in another
See how relationships between continuous variables differ across categorical groups
Displays the patterns analyzed in correlations, regression


So now we want to tackle this issue. How do these relationships differ across groups?

title: Week 5 Seminar: Relationships between Variables
text:
Scatter Plot: Category Differences
distinguish between groups


Let’s go back to this basic plot.
PROMPT: can anyone think of how we might add to or change our basic scatterplot to visually distinguish between the groups, between people with different job_roles?
(color, facets)

title: Week 5 Seminar: Relationships between Variables
text:
Scatter Plot: Category Differences
distinguish between groups: aes(color = cat_var)

ggplot(customer_ops, aes(task_switch_hours, performance_index)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = job_role), alpha = 0.5) + #< add aes(color = )
  geom_smooth(aes(color = job_role), method = "lm") #< add aes(color = )

title: Week 5 Seminar: Relationships between Variables
text:
Scatter Plot: Category Differences
distinguish between groups: aes(color = cat_var)


This is pretty good. It already gives us a sense that that relationship differs between groups.
But it’s also kind of busy. How about trying to split this into different graphs

title: Week 5 Seminar: Relationships between Variables
text:
Scatter Plot: Category Differences
distinguish between groups: facet_wrap(~cat_var)

ggplot(customer_ops, aes(task_switch_hours, performance_index)) +
  facet_wrap(~job_role) + #< separate facets for job_role
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5) + 
  geom_smooth(method = "lm")

title: Week 5 Seminar: Relationships between Variables
text:
Scatter Plot: Category Differences
distinguish between groups: facet_wrap(~cat_var)


Now we see differences clearly.
To connect up to analysis - what kind of analysis might you use to capture these patterns, and what effects would you see?

Might have additional useful information about these employees.
Such as the region where they work, how long they’ve worked there, and some measure of how well they’re performing at a 90 day review.
USE PAINTING
So there might be questions that we want to answer that involve data from these two sets. E.g., we were looking at the relationship between training huors and perfrmance befre. And we had seen that employees with more training hours had a higher performance index.
But maybe that relationship differs across people who have been with the company for different amounts of time. For example, maybe completing more training hours is especially helpful for employees who are just starting out and have been with the company for less than a year.
If we wanted to look at that, we need to pull information from BOTH these datasets.

Now this is what we want to VISUALIZE. We’ve got this correlation matrix, and we can spend a while staring at the numbers and trying to interpret what they mean. For example…
But wouldn’t it be so much easier to grasp these correlations in a visual form? Like, what if we could use color to indicate whether a correlation was positive or negative, and how strong the correlation is?
So that’s our goal. Take this numeric matrix and turn it into a more easy to grasp visual.
At this point we have a couple different options. There are various packages that people have written that visualize correlation matrices.

title: Week 5 Seminar: Relationships between Variables
text:
Summary: Relationships between Variables

Scatterplots are the core tool

Improve readability with transparency, jitter, or binning
Add distributions with marginal plots
Trend lines highlight overall patterns (e.g., linear regression)

Group comparisons

Color and/or facets show differences across categorical groups

Correlational matrices

Visualise many correlations at once

Relational data

Data might be stored in multiple sources
Join by common identifiers



Not just continuous, any kind of variables

title: Independent Study to Prepare
text:
Relationships between Variables
To prepare for diving into this week’s topic, relationships between variables:

Read Data Visualization Ch 12.1 - 12.2

If you haven’t already completed the Data Camp assignments for the preceding weeks, you absolutely should catch up! Seminars and practicals will assume familiarity with the contents of these assignments. As a reminder, they are:

Introduction to the Tidyverse
Categorical Data in the Tidyverse
Reshaping Data with tidyr

title: Practical
text:
In this practical you will work with a tutoring dataset to: (1) create line graphs for values over time, (2) avoid “spaghetti plots” using grouping, faceting, and highlighting, (3) add uncertainty bands, and (4) parse and plot time values stored as strings such as "MM:SS.s" using lubridate and hms.

Practicals are not a test. It is expected that you often don’t know how to start, make a lot of mistakes and need help. It is expected that you are familiar with independent study content before the workshop. However, you need not remember or understand every detail as the workshop should build and consolidate your understanding. Tips

don’t worry about making mistakes
don’t let what you can not do interfere with what you can do
discussing code with your neighbours will help
look things up in the independent study material
look things up in your own code from earlier workshops
there are no stupid questions







Key



These four symbols are used at the beginning of each instruction so you know where to carry out the instruction.
 Something you need to do on your computer. It may be opening programs or documents or locating a file.
 Something you should do in RStudio. It will often be typing a command or using the menus but might also be creating folders, locating or moving files.
 Something you should do in your browser on the internet. It may be searching for information, going to the VLE or downloading a file.
 A question for you to think about and answer. Record your answers in your script for future reference.
crumbs: Week 6: Time Series and Line Plots

title: Practical
text:
Today’s data
We’ll use one CSV called tutoring.csv which contains simulated data about a university tutoring service. Each row corresponds to data for one tutor in one term.
Key columns you’ll use today:


tutor_id (integer identifier)

experience (novice, mid, expert)

year (integer year, e.g., 2021)

term (winter, spring, summer, autumn)

policy (human vs ai_assist)

student_satisfaction (0–100 scale)

metric (wait_time or session_time)

mmss (character string like "03:48.4" or "29:55.8")

Load the data
 Save this file in your week-6 folder:

tutor.csv

 Add the following code to your R script and run. Note that we will specify col_types in read_csv to force the mmss variable to be read in as a character string. If we did not do this, read_csv might try to read it in as a time but parse it incorrectly, leading to NA values. To do this, we need to specify the type for each column:

tutor <- read_csv("tutor.csv",
                  col_types = list(col_integer(),   # tutor_id
                                   col_factor(),    # experience
                                   col_integer(),   # year
                                   col_factor(),    # term
                                   col_factor(),    # policy
                                   col_double(),    # student_satisfaction
                                   col_factor(),   # metric
                                   col_character()) # mmss
                  )
crumbs: Week 6: Time Series and Line Plots

title: Practical
text:
Look at the data
 Examine the variables and first few rows of tutor using head().

head(tutor)

# A tibble: 6 × 8
  tutor_id experience  year term   policy    student_satisfaction metric   mmss 
     <int> <fct>      <int> <fct>  <fct>                    <dbl> <fct>    <chr>
1        1 mid         2021 winter human                    100   wait_ti… 2570…
2        1 mid         2021 winter human                    100   session… 36:2…
3        1 mid         2021 spring human                    100   wait_ti… 2451…
4        1 mid         2021 spring human                    100   session… 26:3…
5        1 mid         2021 summer ai_assist                 50.5 wait_ti… 3524…
6        1 mid         2021 summer ai_assist                 69.8 session… 35:2…
crumbs: Week 6: Time Series and Line Plots

title: Practical
text:
Tidy factor order
In this dataset, experience has a natural order from junior to senior and term has a natural order from winter to autumn.
 Reorder the levels of experience and season.

tutor <- tutor %>%
  mutate(experience = factor(experience,
                             levels = c("novice","mid","expert")),
         term = factor(term,
                             levels = c("winter", "spring", "summer", "autumn")))

 Why is it helpful to make the order explicit before plotting?
crumbs: Week 6: Time Series and Line Plots

title: Practical
section: Create a date from year and term
text:
Create a date from year and term

We’ll create a single date column representing the first month of each academic term (Winter=Jan, Spring=Apr, Summer=Jul, Autumn=Oct).
 Use case_when() to map term → month, then combine with ym().

tutor <- tutor %>%
  mutate(month = case_when(
    term == "winter" ~ 1,
    term == "spring" ~ 4,
    term == "summer" ~ 7,
    term == "autumn" ~ 10
  ),
  year_month = ym(paste(year, month)))  # Date at first-of-month

 Check the new variable.

tutor %>% 
  select(year, term, month, year_month) %>% 
  head()

# A tibble: 6 × 4
   year term   month year_month
  <int> <fct>  <dbl> <date>    
1  2021 winter     1 2021-01-01
2  2021 winter     1 2021-01-01
3  2021 spring     4 2021-04-01
4  2021 spring     4 2021-04-01
5  2021 summer     7 2021-07-01
6  2021 summer     7 2021-07-01
crumbs: Week 6: Time Series and Line Plots

title: Practical
text:
Exercise 1: Mean satisfaction over time
 Plot how student_satisfaction changes over year_month with a line and a light uncertainty ribbon depicting mean_se (standard error of the mean). Label the x-axis date as year-month.








 Does satisfaction tend to increase or decrease across years? Any clear term-to-term pattern?
crumbs: Week 6: Time Series and Line Plots

title: Practical
text:
Exercise 2: Compare policies over time
 Plot how student_satisfaction changes over year with different lines / uncertainty ribbons in different colors for policy.








 Do the policies diverge or converge over time?
crumbs: Week 6: Time Series and Line Plots

title: Practical
section: Exercise 3: Avoiding spaghetti — facet by experience
text:
Exercise 3: Avoiding spaghetti — facet by experience
What if we wanted to look at how the change in student_satisfaction by policy over year differs across tutors with different levels of experience? This would be a lot to cram into one plot - multiple lines would overlap and make them difficult to disentangle.
When multiple groups overlap, it can be easier to facet.
 Adapt your code from the previous exercise to facet by experience. Recall that the default facets will show plots horizontally side-by-side, but you can show them vertically by setting nrow to the number of facets (here, the number of experience levels, which is 3). Consider whether it is easier to perceive trends and differences when panels are organized horizontally versus vertically.
 Do the different experience levels show similar effects of policy over time? How does uncertainty / variability influence your perception of effects (if any)?
crumbs: Week 6: Time Series and Line Plots

title: Practical
section: Exercise 4: Parse "mmss" into a time variable
text:
Exercise 4: Parse "mmss" into a time variable
The mmss column is a character string like "03:48.4". We’ll parse it into a proper time class for plotting.
 Generate a new variable in the tutor dataset: use lubridate::ms() (minutes/seconds) to create a variable called mmss_period for nice axis formatting.

tutor %>% 
  select(metric, mmss, mmss_period) %>% 
  head()

# A tibble: 6 × 3
  metric       mmss      mmss_period
  <fct>        <chr>     <Period>   
1 wait_time    2570:45.9 2570M 45.9S
2 session_time 36:22.3   36M 22.3S  
3 wait_time    2451:01.0 2451M 1S   
4 session_time 26:36.6   26M 36.6S  
5 wait_time    3524:16.3 3524M 16.3S
6 session_time 35:24.3   35M 24.3S  


 Why did we force mmss to character when reading the CSV? What could go wrong if the import guessed a time type automatically?
crumbs: Week 6: Time Series and Line Plots

title: Practical
section: Exercise 5: Plot time metrics over years
text:
Exercise 5: Plot time metrics over years
Look at how wait time changes from one year to the next
 Filter the tutor dataset to just metric == "wait_time" and plot mean mmss_period by year with a ribbon.
crumbs: Week 6: Time Series and Line Plots

title: Practical
text:
Exercise 6: Compare wait_time vs session_time

We’ll use the metric column to show how wait_time and session_time change over year.
Note that the ranges of wait_time and session_time are different: wait_time tends to be on the order of days, whereas session_time tends to be on the order of minutes. This will cause problems if we use a common y-axis for both. Here, first create the problematic plot, then edit it to solve the problem.
 Plot means and uncertainty ribbons for mmss_period by year, faceting by metric so that wait_time and session_time appear as different panels.








 See how it is very difficult to see changes in session_time, and the large amount of blank white space for wait_time. Why does this happen?
 Within facet_wrap, set scales = "free_y" to allow different y-axis ranges for the two panels.
crumbs: Week 6: Time Series and Line Plots

title: Practical
section: Exercise 7: Facet by metric, color by experience
text:
Exercise 7: Facet by metric, color by experience
Now let’s add separate lines to see trends in wait_time and session_time for each experience level.
 Adapt your code for the previous exercise to color the lines and fill the ribbons based on experience.








 How do changes in wait_time and session_time differ across experience?
crumbs: Week 6: Time Series and Line Plots

title: Practical
text:
Exercise 8: Drawing attention with highlighting
What if we want to focus on experts versus non-experts, and de-emphasize differences between tutors with mid or novice levels of experience?
 Create a new variable to highlight expert vs others using mutate and ifelse. Adapt your plot from the previous exercise to: (1) color and fill based on your new highlighting variable, and (2) group lines based on the experience variable. Set the scale_color_manual() and scale_fill_manual() values to choose colors that emphasize experts (e.g., expert in blue, non-experts in gray).








 Do experts differ systematically from other groups in wait_time and sesion_time trends?
crumbs: Week 6: Time Series and Line Plots

Set up
If you have just opened RStudio you will want to load the tidyverse package.

title: Independent Study to Consolidate
text:
Reading in data
 Save this file in your week-6 folder:

Telehealth dataset: telehealth.csv


 Add the following code to your R script and run:

telehealth <- read_csv("telehealth.csv", 
                 col_types = list(
                 col_integer(),
                 col_factor(),
                 col_integer(),
                 col_factor(),
                 col_factor(),
                 col_double(),
                 col_factor(),
                 col_character()))


head(telehealth)

# A tibble: 6 × 8
  agent_id seniority  year season policy    patient_satisfaction metric    mmss 
     <int> <fct>     <int> <fct>  <fct>                    <dbl> <fct>     <chr>
1        1 mid        2021 winter hybrid_ai                 55.2 first_re… 06:3…
2        1 mid        2021 winter hybrid_ai                 55.2 handle_t… 21:1…
3        1 mid        2021 winter hybrid_ai                 55.2 resoluti… 116:…
4        1 mid        2021 spring hybrid_ai                 64.4 first_re… 04:5…
5        1 mid        2021 spring hybrid_ai                 64.4 handle_t… 17:0…
6        1 mid        2021 spring hybrid_ai                 64.4 resoluti… 85:5…
crumbs: Week 6: Time Series and Line Plots

title: Independent Study to Consolidate
text:
Exercise 1: Satisfaction over time
Let’s start out by looking at changes in satisfaction over time.
 Generate a plot that shows how patient_satisfaction changes over year.
Reflect: Do you see satisfaction trending up, down, or flat across years?
crumbs: Week 6: Time Series and Line Plots

title: Independent Study to Consolidate
text:
Exercise 2: Policy comparison
Now let’s see how the changes differ across the two policies.
 Use different-colored lines and ribbons to show how the change in patient_satisfaction over year differs across policies.
Reflect: Do the policies diverge or converge over the years?
crumbs: Week 6: Time Series and Line Plots

title: Independent Study to Consolidate
text:
Exercise 3: Faceting by seniority
Now let’s see how differences between policies in trends over time differ across agents with different levels of seniority.
First, we’ll want to order the levels of the seniority variable from least to most seniority.
 Use mutate to specify the order of the seniority factor levels as junior, mid, senior.
 Use facets to contrast the changes in patient_satisfaction over years for the different policies across levels of seniority.
Reflect: Does the effect of policy differ across junior, mid, and senior agents?
crumbs: Week 6: Time Series and Line Plots

title: Independent Study to Consolidate
text:
Exercise 4: Parse time values
The mmss column stores durations like "06:30.7" or "116:08.0" as character strings.
 Convert mmss into a time variable called mmss_period using ms(), then convert mmss_period into an h:m:s-format time variable using hms::hms().
Reflect: Why did we import mmss as character instead of letting read_csv guess a time type? What goes wrong for strings like "116:08.0"?
crumbs: Week 6: Time Series and Line Plots

title: Independent Study to Consolidate
text:
Exercise 5: Compare all metrics
The dataset has three time metrics (first_response, handle_time, resolution_time) on very different scales.
Let’s visualize trends in the three metrics in different panels.
 Plot the changes in mmss_hms over year with separate lines for policy and separate facets for metric. Free up the y-axis ranges as needed.
Reflect: Why is scales = "free_y" helpful here? What happens without it?
crumbs: Week 6: Time Series and Line Plots

title: Overview
text:
This week you will learn how to customize your plots for clarity and appeal. Note that the preparation for this week includes multiple chapters from the module textbook, but each one is quite short.

Learning objectives
The successful student will be able to:

customize plot labels and axes to be clear and readable
polish the appearance of plots to make labels legible, reduce clutter, and increase visual appeal
combine multiple facets and plots to help the viewer synthesize and compare patterns

title: Week 7 Seminar: Advanced Customizations
text:
From last time

Time series and line graphs
Multiple groups & avoiding “spaghetti” plots
Working with dates (lubridate)
Line graphs for ordered variables (dose, distance, intensity)

title: Week 7 Seminar: Advanced Customizations
text:
Content so far: Explore


We’ve been learning how to create different kinds of plots
Focus has been on mechanics of getting data into a plot
The plots we’ve made so far are good enough if we want to explore data ourselves

See what patterns exist in the data
Probe for issues to consider in analyses, like outliers

But they haven’t been optimised for communicating with other people

title: Week 7 Seminar: Advanced Customizations
text:
Content going forward: Explain

Our plots should:

Draw the viewer’s eyes to the key pattern
Be easy to understand

title: Week 7 Seminar: Advanced Customizations
text:
Content going forward: Explain


Producing viewer-friendly plots:

Use clear, readable labels
Use elements like color to highlight key patterns
Reduce clutter
Avoid redundancy (e.g., same variable labeled in axis and legend)
Use facets or multi-panel layouts to facilitate comparisons

title: Week 7 Seminar: Advanced Customizations
text:
Two base plots

# Scatter (continuous x/y + color by group)
p_scatter <- psych_df %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = stress_score, y = sleep_hours)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = diagnosis))

# Bar (grouped mean + fill by group)
p_bar <- psych_df %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = diagnosis, y = stress_score)) +
  stat_summary(aes(fill = diagnosis), fun = "mean", geom = "bar")

title: Week 7 Seminar: Advanced Customizations
text:
Labels with labs()
basic labels

# Add title, subtitle, and axis labels
p_scatter +
  labs(
    title    = "Stress vs. Sleep",
    subtitle = "Color indicates diagnosis group",
    x = "Stress score (0–100)",
    y = "Sleep hours (per night)"
  )

label legend aes() variables

# Can use labs for legends / aesthetics 
p_scatter +
  labs(
    color   = "Diagnosis"
  )

  theme_bw() +

    legend.position = "top",

title: Week 7 Seminar: Advanced Customizations
text:
Today

Labels with labs()
scale_*_* to customize breaks, labels, limits, and colors
Polishing visuals with theme()
Annotations, text, and direct labeling for clarity
Faceting: facet_wrap, facet_grid, and patchwork

title: Week 7 Seminar: Advanced Customizations
text:
Annotations & direct labeling


Right now, one of the things that leaps out from this plot is that people with a diagnosis of anxiety or depression have higher stress scores
But if someone wanted to know what the exact scores for each group were, they’d need to try to mentally line up the heights of the bars with the y-axis.
If we want those exact values to be something that’s easy for the reader to see, we can label them on the graph.

title: Week 7 Seminar: Advanced Customizations
text:
Annotations & direct labeling
geom_text()

# Get mean stress scores for each group
bar_means <- psych_df %>%
  group_by(diagnosis) %>%
  summarise(mean_stress = round(mean(stress_score, na.rm = TRUE), 1))

# Add a geom_text 
p_bar +
  geom_text(data = bar_means, # use the tibble we generated
            aes(x = diagnosis, y = mean_stress, label = mean_stress), # set the aes
            vjust = -0.3, size = 5) # shift up and make bigger

title: Week 7 Seminar: Advanced Customizations
text:
Annotations & direct labeling


Now let’s go to this plot.
Perhaps here, we want to make it really easy to see which points correspond to each diagnosis, without people having to look at the legend.
So maybe we’d want to put nice clear labels in the middle of each group to label it as anxiety, depression, none
that geom_text might not be ideal because it might be difficult to read text on top of the points
so we’ll use something slightly different called geom_label to format the text in a nice labeled box

title: Week 7 Seminar: Advanced Customizations
text:
Annotations & direct labeling
geom_text()

# Calculate where the center of each group lies on the
# stress_score (x-axis) and sleep_hours (y-axis) variables
group_centers <- psych_df %>%
  group_by(diagnosis) %>%
  summarise(
    stress_center = mean(stress_score, na.rm = TRUE),
    sleep_center  = mean(sleep_hours,  na.rm = TRUE))

p_scatter +
  geom_label(data = group_centers,
             aes(x = stress_center, y = sleep_center, label = diagnosis, color = diagnosis),
             show.legend = FALSE, 
             size = 5, label.size = 0.25) +
  theme(legend.position = "none") # get rid of the redundant legend

title: Week 7 Seminar: Advanced Customizations
text:
Today

Labels with labs()
scale_*_* to customize breaks, labels, limits and colors
Polishing visuals with theme()
Annotations, text, and direct labeling for clarity
Faceting: facet_wrap, facet_grid, and patchwork

title: Week 7 Seminar: Advanced Customizations
text:
Faceting
compare groups without clutter

p_scatter +
  stat_smooth(aes(color = diagnosis), method = "lm") #add regression line per group

title: Week 7 Seminar: Advanced Customizations
text:
Faceting: wrap
compare groups without clutter

p_scatter +
  facet_wrap(~diagnosis) + #facet by diagnosis
  stat_smooth(aes(color = diagnosis), method = "lm") +
  theme(legend.position = "none", #facet labels make diagnosis legend redundant
        strip.background = element_blank()) #remove gray background of facet labels

title: Week 7 Seminar: Advanced Customizations
text:
Faceting: grid
compare groups without clutter

p_scatter +
  facet_grid(sex~diagnosis) + # rows and columns
  stat_smooth(aes(color = diagnosis), method = "lm") + 
  theme(legend.position = "none",
        strip.background = element_blank())

title: Week 7 Seminar: Advanced Customizations
text:
Faceting: grid
revise labels

p_scatter +
  facet_grid(sex~diagnosis, 
             labeller = labeller(sex = c(Female = "Sex: Female", Male = "Sex: Male")) ) + # label rows
  stat_smooth(aes(color = diagnosis), method = "lm") + 
  theme(legend.position = "none",
        strip.background = element_blank())

title: Week 7 Seminar: Advanced Customizations
text:
Faceting: grid
revise labels

p_scatter +
  facet_grid(sex~diagnosis, 
             labeller = labeller(sex = ~ paste("Sex:", .x))) + # label rows
  stat_smooth(aes(color = diagnosis), method = "lm") + 
  theme(legend.position = "none",
        strip.background = element_blank())

title: Week 7 Seminar: Advanced Customizations
text:
Patchwork: combine multiple plots

library(patchwork)

title: Week 7 Seminar: Advanced Customizations
text:
Patchwork: combine multiple plots
horizontal

p_scatter + p_bar


Uses arithmetic-like notation to combine plots in a readable way

title: Week 7 Seminar: Advanced Customizations
text:
Patchwork: combine multiple plots
vertical

p_scatter / p_bar

title: Week 7 Seminar: Advanced Customizations
text:
Patchwork: combine multiple plots
nested

p_scatter | (p_scatter / p_bar)

title: Week 7 Seminar: Advanced Customizations
text:
Patchwork: combine multiple plots
label

p_scatter + p_bar +
plot_annotation(tag_levels = 'A')

title: Week 7 Seminar: Advanced Customizations
text:
Summary

Use labs() to control labels (title, subtitle, caption, axes, legend titles).
Use scale_*_* to control how scales are used/shown
Use theme() to control presentation (grid, legend, typography)

Emphasize clarity with annotations and direct labels.

Use facets and patchwork to structure comparisons

title: Independent Study to Prepare
text:
Advanced Customizations
To prepare for diving into this week’s topic, advanced customization:

Read Data Visualization Ch 20 - 24. Note: This might seem like several chapters, but they are each very short.

You may also make progress on the DataCamp assignment for the following week:

Communicating with Data in the Tidyverse - Chapter 3 Introduction to RMarkdown

title: Practical
text:
In this practical you’ll build a small Quarto project from scratch and create a mini HTML report based on the wellbeing dataset, using the ideas from Seminar 8:

Setting up a project folder with a subfolder for data
Creating a .qmd report file inside an RStudio project
Writing a YAML header for an HTML report
Adding a setup chunk that loads packages and data
Writing sections using Markdown (headings, paragraphs, lists)
Adding code chunks that generate tables and figures
Using chunk options (echo, include, fig-cap, out-width)

Inserting inline code (e.g., for sample sizes) in the text
Rendering the report and dealing with common errors

By the end, you should have your first complete Quarto report for this module, using a dataset on sleep and wellbeing.

Practicals are not a test. It is expected that you often don’t know how to start, make a lot of mistakes and need help. It is expected that you are familiar with independent study content before the workshop. However, you need not remember or understand every detail as the workshop should build and consolidate your understanding. Tips:

don’t worry about making mistakes

don’t let what you can not do interfere with what you can do

discussing code with your neighbours will help

look things up in the independent study material

look things up in your own code from earlier workshops

there are no stupid questions







Key



These four symbols are used at the beginning of each instruction so you know where to carry out the instruction.
 Something you need to do on your computer. It may be opening programs or documents or locating a file.
 Something you should do in RStudio. It will often be typing a command or using the menus but might also be creating folders, locating or moving files.
 Something you should do in your browser on the internet. It may be searching for information, going to the VLE or downloading a file.
 A question for you to think about and answer. Record your answers in your report or script for future reference.
